events.title: Narrator's Introduction and the Captain's Arrival
detailed_summary: The narrator, Jim Hawkins, explains he is writing the story of Treasure Island at the request of Squire Trelawney and Dr. Livesey, omitting only the island's exact location due to remaining treasure.
He begins his account from the time his father ran the Admiral Benbow inn and a rugged old seaman first arrived.
Jim vividly recalls the seaman's appearance: tall, strong, with a tarry pigtail, scarred hands, black, broken nails, and a prominent sabre cut across one cheek.
The seaman surveyed the cove, whistled to himself, and then sang his characteristic sea-song: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
He rapped on the inn door with a stick and, when Jim's father appeared, roughly ordered a glass of rum, which he drank slowly while appraising the surroundings.
Declaring the inn a suitable 'berth,' he instructed the man with his sea-chest to bring it inside, stating his simple needs: rum, bacon, eggs, and a vantage point to watch for ships.
He asked to be called 'captain' and threw down three or four gold pieces, telling them to inform him when the money had been 'worked through.'
Despite his poor clothing and coarse speech, he possessed an air of command, like a mate or skipper accustomed to being obeyed.

The man who delivered the chest informed them that the captain had arrived by mail coach the previous morning, inquired about coastal inns, and, hearing theirs was well-regarded and secluded, had chosen it for his residence.

events.text_segment:
Squire Trelawney, Dr. Livesey, and the rest of these gentlemen having asked me to write down the whole particulars about Treasure Island, from the beginning to the end, keeping nothing back but the bearings of the island, and that only because there is still treasure not yet lifted, I take up my pen in the year of grace 17—, and go back to the time when my father kept the Admiral Benbow inn and the brown old seaman with the sabre cut first took up his lodging under our roof.
I remember him as if it were yesterday, as he came plodding to the inn door, his sea-chest following behind him in a hand-barrow—a tall, strong, heavy, nut-brown man, his tarry pigtail falling over the shoulder of his soiled blue coat, his hands ragged and scarred, with black, broken nails, and the sabre cut across one cheek, a dirty, livid white. I remember him looking round the cove and whistling to himself as he did so, and then breaking out in that old sea-song that he sang so often afterwards: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
in the high, old tottering voice that seemed to have been tuned and broken at the capstan bars. Then he rapped on the door with a bit of stick like a handspike that he carried, and when my father appeared, called roughly for a glass of rum. This, when it was brought to him, he drank slowly, like a connoisseur, lingering on the taste and still looking about him at the cliffs and up at our signboard.
“This is a handy cove,” says he at length; “and a pleasant sittyated grog-shop. Much company, mate?”
My father told him no, very little company, the more was the pity.
“Well, then,” said he, “this is the berth for me. Here you, matey,” he cried to the man who trundled the barrow; “bring up alongside and help up my chest. I’ll stay here a bit,” he continued. “I’m a plain man; rum and bacon and eggs is what I want, and that head up there for to watch ships off. What you mought call me? You mought call me captain. Oh, I see what you’re at—there”; and he threw down three or four gold pieces on the threshold. “You can tell me when I’ve worked through that,” says he, looking as fierce as a commander.
And indeed bad as his clothes were and coarsely as he spoke, he had none of the appearance of a man who sailed before the mast, but seemed like a mate or skipper accustomed to be obeyed or to strike. The man who came with the barrow told us the mail had set him down the morning before at the Royal George, that he had inquired what inns there were along the coast, and hearing ours well spoken of, I suppose, and described as lonely, had chosen it from the others for his place of residence. And that was all we could learn of our guest.

events.title: The Captain's Mysterious Habits and Jim's Secret Task
detailed_summary: The captain generally maintained a very quiet and reserved demeanor.
He spent his days observing the cove or the cliffs with a brass telescope.
In the evenings, he would sit in a corner of the parlor by the fire, drinking very strong rum and water.
He usually wouldn't speak when addressed, merely looking up suddenly and fiercely and blowing through his nose like a fog-horn, which led people to leave him alone.
Every day upon returning from his walk, he would inquire if any seafaring men had passed by on the road.
Initially, this was thought to be a desire for companionship, but it eventually became clear he wished to avoid such men.
When a seaman did stay at the Admiral Benbow, the captain would peer at him through the curtained door before entering the parlor and would remain completely silent in their presence.
Jim Hawkins understood the captain's anxieties, as he had been enlisted to help.
The captain had privately promised Jim a silver fourpenny on the first of each month if Jim would keep a lookout for a 'seafaring man with one leg' and inform him immediately of his appearance.

Frequently, when Jim asked for his monthly payment, the captain would initially just snort and stare him down, but he would invariably pay within the week and reiterate his instructions about the one-legged man.

events.text_segment: He was a very silent man by custom. All day he hung round the cove or upon the cliffs with a brass telescope; all evening he sat in a corner of the parlour next the fire and drank rum and water very strong. Mostly he would not speak when spoken to, only look up sudden and fierce and blow through his nose like a fog-horn; and we and the people who came about our house soon learned to let him be. Every day when he came back from his stroll he would ask if any seafaring men had gone by along the road. At first we thought it was the want of company of his own kind that made him ask this question, but at last we began to see he was desirous to avoid them. When a seaman did put up at the Admiral Benbow (as now and then some did, making by the coast road for Bristol) he would look in at him through the curtained door before he entered the parlour; and he was always sure to be as silent as a mouse when any such was present. For me, at least, there was no secret about the matter, for I was, in a way, a sharer in his alarms. He had taken me aside one day and promised me a silver fourpenny on the first of every month if I would only keep my “weather-eye open for a seafaring man with one leg” and let him know the moment he appeared. Often enough when the first of the month came round and I applied to him for my wage, he would only blow through his nose at me and stare me down, but before the week was out he was sure to think better of it, bring me my four-penny piece, and repeat his orders to look out for “the seafaring man with one leg.”

He was a very silent man by custom. Even when he spoke, his words were few and carefully chosen, as if each syllable cost him dearly. The other men at the inn, whether regulars or passing strangers, soon learned not to press him for stories or opinions. He would sit in the corner, his back to the wall, his eyes always alert and watchful, scanning the room with a wary intelligence. The only sound that often accompanied him was the slow, rhythmic tapping of his fingers on the table, a habit that seemed to betray some inner restlessness.

Despite his silence, there was an air of authority about him that none could deny. The local folk, and even my own father, treated him with a mixture of respect and fear. His presence seemed to fill the room, and when he entered, conversations would falter and laughter would die away. He was not a man to be trifled with, and even the boldest of the sailors who frequented the Admiral Benbow Inn thought twice before crossing him.

He kept to himself, rarely venturing out except for his daily walks along the cliffs, where he would stand for hours gazing out to sea. Sometimes, I would watch him from a distance, wondering what thoughts occupied his mind, what memories haunted his silent hours. There was a mystery about him, a sense that he carried secrets too heavy to share.

Yet, for all his reticence, there were moments when his guard would slip. Late at night, after a few glasses of rum, he might mutter a word or two about distant lands or lost companions. His eyes would grow distant, and for a brief moment, the mask would fall away, revealing a glimpse of the man he once was. But these moments were rare, and by morning, he would be as silent and impenetrable as ever, a living enigma in our quiet inn.

events.title: Jim's Nightmares and the Captain's Tyrannical Evenings
detailed_summary: Jim explains that the figure of the one-legged seafaring man deeply troubled his dreams, appearing in countless forms and with diabolical expressions, sometimes with a leg severed at the knee or hip, or as a monstrous single-legged creature.

events.text_segment:
How that personage haunted my dreams, I need scarcely tell you. On stormy nights, when the wind shook the four corners of the house and the surf roared along the cove and up the cliffs, I would see him in a thousand forms, and with a thousand diabolical expressions. Now the leg would be cut off at the knee, now at the hip; now he was a monstrous kind of a creature who had never had but the one leg, and that in the middle of his body. To see him leap and run and pursue me over hedge and ditch was the worst of nightmares. And altogether I paid pretty dear for my monthly fourpenny piece, in the shape of these abominable fancies.
But though I was so terrified by the idea of the seafaring man with one leg, I was far less afraid of the captain himself than anybody else who knew him. There were nights when he took a deal more rum and water than his head would carry; and then he would sometimes sit and sing his wicked, old, wild sea-songs, minding nobody; but sometimes he would call for glasses round and force all the trembling company to listen to his stories or bear a chorus to his singing. Often I have heard the house shaking with “Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum,” all the neighbours joining in for dear life, with the fear of death upon them, and each singing louder than the other to avoid remark. For in these fits he was the most overriding companion ever known; he would slap his hand on the table for silence all round; he would fly up in a passion of anger at a question, or sometimes because none was put, and so he judged the company was not following his story. Nor would he allow anyone to leave the inn till he had drunk himself sleepy and reeled off to bed.

events.title: The Captain's Dreadful Stories, Financial Strain, and the Father's Decline
detailed_summary: The captain's tales were the most terrifying aspect for the inn's patrons, filled with accounts of hangings, walking the plank, sea storms, the Dry Tortugas, and wild deeds and locations on the Spanish Main.

Based on his own accounts, he must have lived among some of the most wicked men ever to sail the seas, and the language he used shocked the local country folk nearly as much as the crimes he narrated.
Jim's father constantly expressed fears that the inn would be ruined, as people would eventually stop coming to be tyrannized and frightened.

However, Jim believed the captain's presence, though frightening at the time, was ultimately a positive influence, providing a source of excitement in their quiet country life; some younger men even feigned admiration for him, calling him a 'true sea-dog.'
The captain was indeed on a path to ruin them financially, as he continued to stay week after week, and then month after month, long after his initial payment was exhausted.
Jim's father never found the courage to insist on further payment.
If his father ever mentioned the debt, the captain would blow through his nose so loudly it sounded like a roar and stare him out of the room.
Jim witnessed his father wringing his hands after such dismissals and is convinced that the constant annoyance and terror contributed significantly to his father's premature and unhappy death.

events.text_segment:
His stories were what frightened people worst of all. Dreadful stories they were—about hanging, and walking the plank, and storms at sea, and the Dry Tortugas, and wild deeds and places on the Spanish Main. By his own account he must have lived his life among some of the wickedest men that God ever allowed upon the sea, and the language in which he told these stories shocked our plain country people almost as much as the crimes that he described. My father was always saying the inn would be ruined, for people would soon cease coming there to be tyrannized over and put down, and sent shivering to their beds; but I really believe his presence did us good. People were frightened at the time, but on looking back they rather liked it; it was a fine excitement in a quiet country life, and there was even a party of the younger men who pretended to admire him, calling him a “true sea-dog” and a “real old salt” and such like names, and saying there was the sort of man that made England terrible at sea.
In one way, indeed, he bade fair to ruin us, for he kept on staying week after week, and at last month after month, so that all the money had been long exhausted, and still my father never plucked up the heart to insist on having more. If ever he mentioned it, the captain blew through his nose so loudly that you might say he roared, and stared my poor father out of the room. I have seen him wringing his hands after such a rebuff, and I am sure the annoyance and the terror he lived in must have greatly hastened his early and unhappy death.

events.title: The Captain's Unchanging State and Dr. Livesey's Arrival
detailed_summary: Throughout his entire stay, the only alteration the captain made to his attire was the purchase of some stockings from a traveling salesman.
One of the decorative points of his hat had fallen, and he let it hang unrepaired, despite it being an inconvenience in windy weather.
Jim recalls the state of the captain's coat, which he mended himself in his room, until it was eventually nothing but a collection of patches.
The captain never wrote or received any letters and only spoke with neighbors, and then typically only when he was drunk on rum.
His large sea-chest remained unopened and its contents a mystery to everyone at the inn.
The captain was seriously challenged on only one occasion, which occurred towards the end of his stay when Jim's father was severely ill and declining.

Dr. Livesey arrived late one afternoon to see the patient (Jim's father), had a quick meal provided by Jim's mother, and then went into the parlor to smoke his pipe while waiting for his horse to be brought from the hamlet.

Jim followed Dr. Livesey into the parlor and distinctly remembered noticing the stark difference between the tidy, bright doctor, with his snow-white powdered wig and pleasant demeanor, and the rustic local people, but especially the contrast with their own 'filthy, heavy, bleared scarecrow of a pirate,' the captain, who was sitting deeply intoxicated with his arms on the table.

All the time he lived with us the captain made no change whatever in his dress but to buy some stockings from a hawker. One of the cocks of his hat having fallen down, he let it hang from that day forth, though it was a great annoyance when it blew. I remember the appearance of his coat, which he patched himself upstairs in his room, and which, before the end, was nothing but patches. He never wrote or received a letter, and he never spoke with any but the neighbours, and with these, for the most part, only when drunk on rum. The great sea-chest none of us had ever seen open.
He was only once crossed, and that was towards the end, when my poor father was far gone in a decline that took him off. Dr. Livesey came late one afternoon to see the patient, took a bit of dinner from my mother, and went into the parlour to smoke a pipe until his horse should come down from the hamlet, for we had no stabling at the old Benbow. I followed him in, and I remember observing the contrast the neat, bright doctor, with his powder as white as snow and his bright, black eyes and pleasant manners, made with the coltish country folk, and above all, with that filthy, heavy, bleared scarecrow of a pirate of ours, sitting, far gone in rum, with his arms on the table.

events.title: The Confrontation: Dr. Livesey vs. The Captain
characters: Old Taylor (the gardener, mentioned by Dr. Livesey)
detailed_summary: The captain abruptly started singing his usual sea shanty about 'Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest.'
Jim reflects that he initially thought 'the dead man’s chest' referred to the captain's large box upstairs, a notion that had merged with his nightmares about the one-legged man.

By this point, everyone was accustomed to the song except Dr. Livesey, upon whom Jim observed it had an unpleasant effect; the doctor looked up angrily for a moment before resuming his conversation with old Taylor, the gardener, about a new rheumatism treatment.
Meanwhile, the captain grew more animated by his own singing and eventually slapped his hand on the table—a gesture everyone recognized as a demand for silence.
All voices stopped instantly, except for Dr. Livesey's, who continued speaking clearly and kindly, taking puffs from his pipe.
The captain glared at Dr. Livesey, slapped his hand again, glared even more intensely, and finally swore, ordering, 'Silence, there, between decks!'

Dr. Livesey inquired if the captain was addressing him, and upon the captain's affirmative (accompanied by another oath), the doctor stated he had only one thing to say: if the captain persisted in drinking rum, the world would soon be rid of a 'very dirty scoundrel.'
The captain's fury was immense; he jumped to his feet, drew and opened a sailor's clasp-knife, and, balancing it on his palm, threatened to pin the doctor to the wall.

Dr. Livesey remained completely unmoved, speaking over his shoulder in the same calm but loud tone, ensuring everyone could hear: 'If you do not put that knife this instant in your pocket, I promise, upon my honour, you shall hang at the next assizes.'
A tense exchange of looks followed, but the captain soon relented, put away his weapon, and sat back down, grumbling like a defeated dog.

Dr. Livesey then asserted that, knowing such a person was in his district, he, as both a doctor and a magistrate, would keep a constant watch on the captain and would take decisive action if there were any complaints, even for incivility like that night's.
Shortly thereafter, Dr. Livesey's horse arrived, and he departed. The captain remained subdued that evening and for many evenings that followed.

events.text_segment:
Suddenly he—the captain, that is—began to pipe up his eternal song: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum! Drink and the devil had done for the rest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
At first I had supposed “the dead man’s chest” to be that identical big box of his upstairs in the front room, and the thought had been mingled in my nightmares with that of the one-legged seafaring man. But by this time we had all long ceased to pay any particular notice to the song; it was new, that night, to nobody but Dr. Livesey, and on him I observed it did not produce an agreeable effect, for he looked up for a moment quite angrily before he went on with his talk to old Taylor, the gardener, on a new cure for the rheumatics. In the meantime, the captain gradually brightened up at his own music, and at last flapped his hand upon the table before him in a way we all knew to mean silence. The voices stopped at once, all but Dr. Livesey’s; he went on as before speaking clear and kind and drawing briskly at his pipe between every word or two. The captain glared at him for a while, flapped his hand again, glared still harder, and at last broke out with a villainous, low oath, “Silence, there, between decks!”
“Were you addressing me, sir?” says the doctor; and when the ruffian had told him, with another oath, that this was so, “I have only one thing to say to you, sir,” replies the doctor, “that if you keep on drinking rum, the world will soon be quit of a very dirty scoundrel!”
The old fellow’s fury was awful. He sprang to his feet, drew and opened a sailor’s clasp-knife, and balancing it open on the palm of his hand, threatened to pin the doctor to the wall.
The doctor never so much as moved. He spoke to him as before, over his shoulder and in the same tone of voice, rather high, so that all the room might hear, but perfectly calm and steady: “If you do not put that knife this instant in your pocket, I promise, upon my honour, you shall hang at the next assizes.”
Then followed a battle of looks between them, but the captain soon knuckled under, put up his weapon, and resumed his seat, grumbling like a beaten dog.
“And now, sir,” continued the doctor, “since I now know there’s such a fellow in my district, you may count I’ll have an eye upon you day and night. I’m not a doctor only; I’m a magistrate; and if I catch a breath of complaint against you, if it’s only for a piece of incivility like tonight’s, I’ll take effectual means to have you hunted down and routed out of this. Let that suffice.”
Soon after, Dr. Livesey’s horse came to the door and he rode away, but the captain held his peace that evening, and for many evenings to come.

It was not very long after this that there occurred the first of the mysterious events that rid us at last of the captain, though not, as you will see, of his affairs. It was a bitter cold winter, with long, hard frosts and heavy gales; and it was plain from the first that my poor father was little likely to see the spring. He sank daily, and my mother and I had all the inn upon our hands, and were kept busy enough without paying much regard to our unpleasant guest.
It was one January morning, very early—a pinching, frosty morning—the cove all grey with hoar-frost, the ripple lapping softly on the stones, the sun still low and only touching the hilltops and shining far to seaward. The captain had risen earlier than usual and set out down the beach, his cutlass swinging under the broad skirts of the old blue coat, his brass telescope under his arm, his hat tilted back upon his head. I remember his breath hanging like smoke in his wake as he strode off, and the last sound I heard of him as he turned the big rock was a loud snort of indignation, as though his mind was still running upon Dr. Livesey.

events.text_segment:
Well, mother was upstairs with father and I was laying the breakfast-table against the captain’s return when the parlour door opened and a man stepped in on whom I had never set my eyes before. He was a pale, tallowy creature, wanting two fingers of the left hand, and though he wore a cutlass, he did not look much like a fighter. I had always my eye open for seafaring men, with one leg or two, and I remember this one puzzled me. He was not sailorly, and yet he had a smack of the sea about him too.
I asked him what was for his service, and he said he would take rum; but as I was going out of the room to fetch it, he sat down upon a table and motioned me to draw near. I paused where I was, with my napkin in my hand.
“Come here, sonny,” says he. “Come nearer here.”
I took a step nearer.
“Is this here table for my mate Bill?” he asked with a kind of leer.
I told him I did not know his mate Bill, and this was for a person who stayed in our house whom we called the captain.
“Well,” said he, “my mate Bill would be called the captain, as like as not. He has a cut on one cheek and a mighty pleasant way with him, particularly in drink, has my mate Bill. We’ll put it, for argument like, that your captain has a cut on one cheek—and we’ll put it, if you like, that that cheek’s the right one. Ah, well! I told you. Now, is my mate Bill in this here house?”
I told him he was out walking.
“Which way, sonny? Which way is he gone?”
And when I had pointed out the rock and told him how the captain was likely to return, and how soon, and answered a few other questions, “Ah,” said he, “this’ll be as good as drink to my mate Bill.”
The expression of his face as he said these words was not at all pleasant, and I had my own reasons for thinking that the stranger was mistaken, even supposing he meant what he said. But it was no affair of mine, I thought; and besides, it was difficult to know what to do. The stranger kept hanging about just inside the inn door, peering round the corner like a cat waiting for a mouse. Once I stepped out myself into the road, but he immediately called me back, and as I did not obey quick enough for his fancy, a most horrible change came over his tallowy face, and he ordered me in with an oath that made me jump. As soon as I was back again he returned to his former manner, half fawning, half sneering, patted me on the shoulder, told me I was a good boy and he had taken quite a fancy to me. “I have a son of my own,” said he, “as like you as two blocks, and he’s all the pride of my ’art. But the great thing for boys is discipline, sonny—discipline. Now, if you had sailed along of Bill, you wouldn’t have stood there to be spoke to twice—not you. That was never Bill’s way, nor the way of sich as sailed with him. And here, sure enough, is my mate Bill, with a spy-glass under his arm, bless his old ’art, to be sure. You and me’ll just go back into the parlour, sonny, and get behind the door, and we’ll give Bill a little surprise—bless his ’art, I say again.”

At sight of Black Dog, the captain stopped short, and for a moment the two men stared at each other in silence. Then, with a sudden movement, the captain advanced, his hand on the hilt of his cutlass.

"You!" he cried. "What do you want here?"

Black Dog rose to his feet, his face twitching. "Easy, Bill," he said. "I only came to have a word with you."

The captain glared at him, but after a moment he seemed to master himself. "Well, speak up, then," he growled.

The two men sat down at the table, and I slipped quietly out of the room, closing the door behind me. I could hear their voices raised in angry dispute, but I could not make out the words. Suddenly, there was a crash, and the door flew open. Black Dog staggered out, blood streaming from a wound on his shoulder, and ran for the door. The captain followed, brandishing his cutlass, but Black Dog was too quick for him and was out of the inn and down the road before the captain could catch him.

The captain stood in the doorway, breathing hard, his face pale and his hand shaking. He looked at me, and for a moment I thought he would fall. Then he straightened himself and came back into the parlour, muttering curses under his breath. I ran to fetch my mother, and together we helped the captain to a chair. He sat there, staring at the door, and would say nothing more about Black Dog or what had passed between them.

events.title: The Captain's Shocking Reunion with Black Dog
detailed_summary: The captain finally entered, closing the door forcefully behind him, and proceeded directly to his breakfast table without scanning the room.
The stranger, attempting a bold tone, called out the name "Bill."
The captain spun around, his face losing all color, his expression one of a man seeing a ghost or something even more dreadful; even his nose appeared blue.
The narrator momentarily felt sorry for the captain, who seemed to age and sicken instantly.
The stranger identified himself, reminding Bill that he was an old shipmate.
The captain audibly gasped and uttered the name, "Black Dog!"

Black Dog affirmed his identity, stating he had come to the Admiral Benbow inn to visit his old companion Billy, and made a reference to their shared past by displaying his mutilated hand, mentioning the loss of his "two talons."
The captain, acknowledging that Black Dog had found him, curtly asked him to state his business.

Black Dog confirmed the captain's understanding and then requested a glass of rum, to be fetched by the narrator, for whom he claimed to have developed a fondness. He proposed they sit down and converse frankly, as old shipmates would.
By the time the narrator returned with the rum, the captain and Black Dog were seated on opposite sides of the breakfast table.
Black Dog had chosen a seat near the door, positioned sideways, allowing him to watch both the captain and, as the narrator presumed, his own potential escape route.
He instructed the narrator to leave the room and to ensure the door remained wide open, explicitly stating he did not want to be spied upon through keyholes.
The narrator complied, leaving them alone and retreating to the bar area.

events.text_segment:
At last in strode the captain, slammed the door behind him, without looking to the right or left, and marched straight across the room to where his breakfast awaited him.
“Bill,” said the stranger in a voice that I thought he had tried to make bold and big.
The captain spun round on his heel and fronted us; all the brown had gone out of his face, and even his nose was blue; he had the look of a man who sees a ghost, or the evil one, or something worse, if anything can be; and upon my word, I felt sorry to see him all in a moment turn so old and sick.
“Come, Bill, you know me; you know an old shipmate, Bill, surely,” said the stranger.
The captain made a sort of gasp.
“Black Dog!” said he.
“And who else?” returned the other, getting more at his ease. “Black Dog as ever was, come for to see his old shipmate Billy, at the Admiral Benbow inn. Ah, Bill, Bill, we have seen a sight of times, us two, since I lost them two talons,” holding up his mutilated hand.
“Now, look here,” said the captain; “you’ve run me down; here I am; well, then, speak up; what is it?”
“That’s you, Bill,” returned Black Dog, “you’re in the right of it, Billy. I’ll have a glass of rum from this dear child here, as I’ve took such a liking to; and we’ll sit down, if you please, and talk square, like old shipmates.”
When I returned with the rum, they were already seated on either side of the captain’s breakfast-table—Black Dog next to the door and sitting sideways so as to have one eye on his old shipmate and one, as I thought, on his retreat.
He bade me go and leave the door wide open. “None of your keyholes for me, sonny,” he said; and I left them together and retired into the bar.

He was a tall, strong, heavy, nut-brown man, his tarry pigtail falling over the shoulder of his soiled blue coat, his hands ragged and scarred, with black, broken nails, and the sabre cut across one cheek, a dirty, livid white. I remember him as if it were yesterday, as he came plodding to the inn door, his sea-chest following behind him in a hand-barrow—a thin, old, ragged, cocksure man, with a look of authority and adventure. He was silent as he entered, and all the guests fell quiet, watching him with a mixture of curiosity and fear. He took his seat at the far end of the table, and, without a word, began to eat his breakfast, his eyes fixed on the plate before him.

My father, who was a quiet, kindly man, ventured to ask if he would like anything more, but the captain only grunted in reply. After a while, he called for a glass of rum, which he drank slowly, rolling it on his tongue and staring out of the window at the sea. When he had finished, he drew a battered old pipe from his pocket and began to smoke, filling the room with the strong, tarry smell of tobacco.

For days he remained at the inn, saying little, but watching everyone who came and went with a keen, suspicious eye. He paid his way, but was surly and rude, and the other guests soon learned to keep their distance. He would go out every day to the headland, where he would stand for hours, looking out to sea, as if expecting someone—or something—to appear on the horizon. At night, he would sit by the fire, drinking rum and singing old sea songs in a rough, broken voice, the words often slurred and indistinct.

events.title: Violent Confrontation and Black Dog's Escape
detailed_summary: Although the narrator made an effort to eavesdrop from the bar, for a considerable duration he could only discern low, indistinct murmuring from the parlour.
Gradually, the voices escalated in volume, and he began to distinguish occasional words, predominantly curses uttered by the captain.
He distinctly heard the captain exclaim at one point, "No, no, no, no; and an end of it!" and later, a defiant statement: "If it comes to swinging, swing all, say I."
The argument culminated in a sudden eruption of loud swearing and other sounds indicative of a physical altercation: furniture was overturned, the clash of steel was heard, followed by a cry of pain.
Immediately thereafter, the narrator witnessed Black Dog fleeing the inn at full speed, with the captain in close pursuit, both men wielding drawn cutlasses.
Black Dog was visibly bleeding from his left shoulder.
As Black Dog reached the inn's doorway, the captain launched a final, formidable sword strike at him.

This powerful blow, which likely would have severely injured Black Dog, was instead intercepted by the large signboard of the Admiral Benbow inn, leaving a tangible mark that is reportedly still visible.
This action marked the conclusion of the physical confrontation.
Once on the road, Black Dog, despite his wound, demonstrated remarkable speed and agility, disappearing over the crest of the hill within half a minute.
The captain, in contrast, remained standing, gazing at the signboard with a perplexed and dazed expression.
He then rubbed his eyes multiple times before finally turning and re-entering the house.

events.text_segment:
For a long time, though I certainly did my best to listen, I could hear nothing but a low gattling; but at last the voices began to grow higher, and I could pick up a word or two, mostly oaths, from the captain.
“No, no, no, no; and an end of it!” he cried once. And again, “If it comes to swinging, swing all, say I.”
Then all of a sudden there was a tremendous explosion of oaths and other noises—the chair and table went over in a lump, a clash of steel followed, and then a cry of pain, and the next instant I saw Black Dog in full flight, and the captain hotly pursuing, both with drawn cutlasses, and the former streaming blood from the left shoulder. Just at the door the captain aimed at the fugitive one last tremendous cut, which would certainly have split him to the chine had it not been intercepted by our big signboard of Admiral Benbow. You may see the notch on the lower side of the frame to this day.
That blow was the last of the battle. Once out upon the road, Black Dog, in spite of his wound, showed a wonderful clean pair of heels and disappeared over the edge of the hill in half a minute. The captain, for his part, stood staring at the signboard like a bewildered man. Then he passed his hand over his eyes several times and at last turned back into the house.

events.title: The Captain's Sudden Collapse
detailed_summary: The captain addressed Jim, requesting rum; as he spoke, he seemed unsteady, staggering slightly and bracing himself with a hand against the wall.
Jim, alarmed, inquired if the captain was injured.
The captain disregarded the question, reiterating his demand for rum and expressing an urgent need to depart from the inn.
As Jim hurried to comply, deeply unsettled by the preceding events, he inadvertently broke a glass and struggled with the rum tap.
While Jim was still fumbling, he heard a significant thud emanating from the parlour.
Rushing into the room, he discovered the captain lying prostrate and unconscious on the floor.
At that very moment, Jim's mother, having been alerted by the sounds of the altercation and shouting, came running downstairs to offer assistance.

Together, Jim and his mother managed to lift the captain's head. He was breathing with great difficulty, making loud, harsh sounds, his eyes were shut, and his facial complexion was disturbingly abnormal.
Jim's mother cried out in distress, lamenting the shameful incident occurring in their home, especially given her husband's illness.
In the immediate aftermath, neither Jim nor his mother knew how to aid the captain, their primary assumption being that he had sustained a fatal injury during the fight with the stranger.
Jim did procure the rum and attempted to administer it to the captain, but his teeth were firmly clenched, and his jaw was rigid.
Their predicament was alleviated by the opportune arrival of Doctor Livesey, who was making a professional visit to Jim's father.

“Jim,” says he, “rum”; and as he spoke, he reeled a little, and caught himself with one hand against the wall.
“Are you hurt?” cried I.
“Rum,” he repeated. “I must get away from here. Rum! Rum!”
I ran to fetch it, but I was quite unsteadied by all that had fallen out, and I broke one glass and fouled the tap, and while I was still getting in my own way, I heard a loud fall in the parlour, and running in, beheld the captain lying full length upon the floor. At the same instant my mother, alarmed by the cries and fighting, came running downstairs to help me. Between us we raised his head. events.title: Dr. Livesey's Intervention and Diagnosis
characters: Captain (Billy Bones, also referred to as Billy Bones/Mr. Bones)
detailed_summary: Jim and his mother anxiously appealed to Dr. Livesey, asking for guidance and inquiring about the location of the captain's supposed wound.
Dr. Livesey summarily dismissed the notion of a wound, asserting that the captain had suffered a stroke, an event he had previously warned the captain about.
He directed Mrs. Hawkins to return to her husband and, if feasible, to avoid alarming him with details of the incident.
Dr. Livesey expressed his resolve to attempt to save the captain's life, despite deeming it "trebly worthless," and requested Jim to bring him a basin.
Upon Jim's return with the basin, he found that Dr. Livesey had already cut open the captain's sleeve, exposing a brawny and muscular arm adorned with several tattoos.
Among the tattoos were inscriptions such as "Here’s luck," "A fair wind," and "Billy Bones his fancy," all legibly and skillfully inked on the forearm.
Higher up, near the shoulder, was a graphic illustration of a gallows with a figure hanging from it, which the narrator thought was rendered with considerable artistic flair.
Dr. Livesey touched the gallows tattoo with his finger and remarked that it was "Prophetic."
Addressing the still-unconscious captain as "Master Billy Bones," the doctor announced his intention to examine the captain's blood and casually asked Jim if he was squeamish about the sight of it.
Jim affirmed that he was not afraid of blood.
Dr. Livesey then instructed Jim to hold the basin, took out his lancet, and proceeded to open a vein on the captain's arm.
A substantial quantity of blood was drawn before the captain finally regained consciousness and looked about him with a hazy, unfocused gaze.

He initially recognized Dr. Livesey, his expression clearly one of displeasure; his gaze then shifted to Jim, and he appeared somewhat reassured. However, his complexion abruptly changed, and he made an effort to sit up, urgently asking about the whereabouts of Black Dog.

events.text_segment:
“Oh, doctor,” we cried, “what shall we do? Where is he wounded?”
“Wounded? A fiddle-stick’s end!” said the doctor. “No more wounded than you or I. The man has had a stroke, as I warned him. Now, Mrs. Hawkins, just you run upstairs to your husband and tell him, if possible, nothing about it. For my part, I must do my best to save this fellow’s trebly worthless life; Jim, you get me a basin.”
When I got back with the basin, the doctor had already ripped up the captain’s sleeve and exposed his great sinewy arm. It was tattooed in several places. “Here’s luck,” “A fair wind,” and “Billy Bones his fancy,” were very neatly and clearly executed on the forearm; and up near the shoulder there was a sketch of a gallows and a man hanging from it—done, as I thought, with great spirit.
“Prophetic,” said the doctor, touching this picture with his finger. “And now, Master Billy Bones, if that be your name, we’ll have a look at the colour of your blood. Jim,” he said, “are you afraid of blood?”
“No, sir,” said I.
“Well, then,” said he, “you hold the basin”; and with that he took his lancet and opened a vein.
A great deal of blood was taken before the captain opened his eyes and looked mistily about him. First he recognized the doctor with an unmistakable frown; then his glance fell upon me, and he looked relieved. But suddenly his colour changed, and he tried to raise himself, crying, “Where’s Black Dog?”

events.title: Dr. Livesey's Dire Warning to the Captain
detailed_summary: Dr. Livesey informed the captain that Black Dog was not present, adding a metaphorical comment about the burdens the captain carried.
He firmly reiterated that the captain's condition was due to excessive rum consumption leading to a stroke, precisely as he had forewarned.
The doctor stated that he had just, with considerable reluctance, managed to save the captain from death.
When Dr. Livesey addressed him as "Mr. Bones," the captain interrupted to say that was not his name.

Dr. Livesey showed little concern for the captain's actual name, explaining he used "Bones" as it was the name of a buccaneer he knew and it served for brevity. He then delivered a critical warning: while a single glass of rum might not be fatal, continued indulgence would inevitably lead to more consumption and ultimately to his death.
He implored the captain to comprehend the seriousness of his condition and to make a genuine effort towards recovery.
Dr. Livesey then offered, for this occasion only, to assist the captain in getting to his bed.
With significant difficulty, Jim and Dr. Livesey together hoisted the captain upstairs and helped him onto his bed, where his head lolled back on the pillow as if he were on the verge of fainting.
As a final, solemn pronouncement, Dr. Livesey declared that his conscience was clear: for the captain, any association with rum signified death.

events.text_segment:
“There is no Black Dog here,” said the doctor, “except what you have on your own back. You have been drinking rum; you have had a stroke, precisely as I told you; and I have just, very much against my own will, dragged you headforemost out of the grave. Now, Mr. Bones—”
“That’s not my name,” he interrupted.
“Much I care,” returned the doctor. “It’s the name of a buccaneer of my acquaintance; and I call you by it for the sake of shortness, and what I have to say to you is this; one glass of rum won’t kill you, but if you take one you’ll take another and another, and I stake my wig if you don’t break off short, you’ll die—do you understand that?—die, and go to your own place, like the man in the Bible. Come, now, make an effort. I’ll help you to your bed for once.”
Between us, with much trouble, we managed to hoist him upstairs, and laid him on his bed, where his head fell back on the pillow as if he were almost fainting.
“Now, mind you,” said the doctor, “I clear my conscience—the name of rum for you is death.”

The captain offers Jim a gold guinea as payment for a noggin of rum.

Concerned for his ailing father's need for tranquility and somewhat insulted by the bribe, Jim agrees to provide only a single glass of rum, emphasizing that his main concern is the debt owed to his father.
After consuming the rum with avidity, the captain inquires about the length of his doctor-ordered confinement.

Learning he must stay in bed for at least a week, he reacts with alarm, fearing his adversaries will deliver the 'black spot' to him within that time, denouncing their unseamanlike tactics and vowing to outmaneuver them.

He makes a strenuous effort to get out of bed, supported by Jim, but his physical frailty is a stark contrast to his defiant words, and he soon collapses back, muttering that the doctor's treatment has enfeebled him.
He then questions Jim about the 'seafaring man' (Black Dog) encountered earlier, labeling him a dangerous individual acting under the influence of even more malevolent figures.

The captain instructs Jim that if he cannot escape and is given the 'black spot,' or if Black Dog or a one-legged seaman reappears, Jim must immediately summon the doctor and local magistrates to secure his sea-chest, which contains the key to Flint's treasure, a secret known only to him.
He clarifies that the 'black spot' serves as a formal summons and pledges to share the rewards equally with Jim if he remains vigilant.

About noon I stopped at the captain’s door with some cooling drinks and medicines. He was lying very much as we had left him, only a little higher, and he seemed both weak and excited.
“Jim,” he said, “you’re the only one here that’s worth anything, and you know I’ve been always good to you. Never a month but I’ve given you a silver fourpenny for yourself. And now you see, mate, I’m pretty low, and deserted by all; and Jim, you’ll bring me one noggin of rum, now, won’t you, matey?”
“The doctor—” I began.
But he broke in cursing the doctor, in a feeble voice but heartily. “Doctors is all swabs,” he said; “and that doctor there, why, what do he know about seafaring men? “Ah! Black Dog,” says he. “He’s a bad ’un; but there’s worse that put him on. Now, if I can’t get away nohow, and they tip me the black spot, mind you, it’s my old sea-chest they’re after; you get on a horse—you can, can’t you? Well, then, you get on a horse, and go to—well, yes, I will!—to that eternal doctor swab, and tell him to pipe all hands—magistrates and sich—and he’ll lay ’em aboard at the Admiral Benbow—all old Flint’s crew, man and boy, all on ’em that’s left. I was first mate, I was, old Flint’s first mate, and I’m the on’y one as knows the place. He gave it me at Savannah, when he lay a-dying, like as if I was to now, you see. But you won’t peach unless they get the black spot on me, or unless you see that Black Dog again or a seafaring man with one leg, Jim—him above all.”
“But what is the black spot, captain?” I asked.
“That’s a summons, mate. I’ll tell you if they get that. But you keep your weather-eye open, Jim, and I’ll share with you equals, upon my honour.”
He wandered a little longer, his voice growing weaker; but soon after I had given him his medicine, which he took like a child, with the remark, “If ever a seaman wanted drugs, it’s me,” he fell at last into a heavy, swoon-like sleep, in which I left him.

I went out to the road and looked up and down, but there was no one in sight. The day was hot and still, and the only sound was the distant breaking of the waves on the shore.

I went back inside and sat by the kitchen fire, thinking over all that had happened. The captain's words kept running in my head, and I could not shake off a feeling of dread. I remembered the black spot and the terrible men who had come to the inn, and I wondered what would happen next.

It was not long before my fears were justified. That very evening, as the sun was setting, I heard a tapping at the window. I looked up and saw a face peering in—a face so evil and cruel that I cried out in terror. My mother came running, and together we barred the door and shuttered the windows.

But the tapping came again, louder this time, and then a voice called out, "Open up, in the name of the law!"

We did not move, and after a while the voice went away. But I knew that we were not safe. The captain was still upstairs, and I could hear him groaning and muttering to himself. I crept up to his room and found him tossing and turning, his face pale and drawn.

"Jim," he said, "they're coming for me. You must be brave, boy. Take this key—it's to my sea-chest. There's something in there that they'll want. But you mustn't let them have it. Promise me, Jim."

I promised, though my heart was pounding with fear. I took the key and hid it in my pocket. Then I went back downstairs and sat with my mother, waiting for whatever would come.

The night was long and full of strange noises. Once or twice I thought I heard footsteps outside, but when I looked, there was nothing there. At last, the dawn came, and with it a sense of relief. But I knew that our troubles were far from over.

The next day, the captain grew worse. He was feverish and delirious, and I had to sit by his side and give him water. He talked of ships and treasure and far-off lands, and sometimes he would call out for his old shipmates. I did my best to comfort him, but I was only a boy, and I was very much afraid.

At last, the end came. The captain gave a great cry and fell back on his pillow. I ran to fetch my mother, but when we returned, he was dead.

We stood by his bedside in silence, not knowing what to do. At last, my mother said, "We must see what is in his chest. He owed us money, and perhaps there is enough to pay his bill."

I remembered the key in my pocket and handed it to her. Together, we went to the captain's room and opened the sea-chest. Inside, we found a bundle of papers, a bag of coins, and some old clothes. My mother took what was owed to her, and I looked through the papers. Among them was a map, marked with strange symbols and the name of an island.

I knew at once that this was the treasure the captain had spoken of. My heart beat fast as I realized that I held in my hands the key to a great adventure.

From that moment, my life was changed forever. I would soon set out on a journey that would take me far from home, across the sea, to the mysterious Treasure Island.

events.title: A Father's Death and the Captain's Troubled Decline
detailed_summary: Jim contemplates informing the doctor about the captain's alarming confessions, partly out of fear that the captain might regret his candor and harm him.
However, this plan is abruptly derailed by the sudden death of Jim's father that same evening, an event that eclipses all other worries.
The family's profound sorrow, coupled with the demands of funeral arrangements and managing the inn, fully occupies Jim, leaving him little time to dwell on the captain or his fears.

The captain manages to come downstairs the next morning, consuming little food but, Jim suspects, more than his usual share of rum, which he helps himself to from the bar with a menacing attitude that deters anyone from challenging him.
The night before the funeral, the captain is exceptionally drunk, his boisterous singing of his coarse sea-shanty deeply inappropriate in the grieving household.
Despite his evident weakness, the family and staff remain terrified of him; meanwhile, the doctor has been called away to a distant case and does not return after Jim's father's passing.

Jim observes that the captain's physical state seems to deteriorate rather than improve, as he struggles to navigate stairs and move about, often relying on walls for support and breathing laboriously.
The captain no longer addresses Jim directly, appearing to have forgotten their earlier confidential exchange.

His temperament becomes increasingly volatile and, considering his physical debility, more violent than ever; he develops an unsettling habit of drawing his cutlass and placing it on the table before him when intoxicated.

Despite these outbursts, he seems more withdrawn into his own thoughts and somewhat disoriented, once astonishing everyone by singing a gentle, old-fashioned country love song, likely learned before his seafaring life.

events.text_segment:
What I should have done had all gone well I do not know. Probably I should have told the whole story to the doctor, for I was in mortal fear lest the captain should repent of his confessions and make an end of me. But as things fell out, my poor father died quite suddenly that evening, which put all other matters on one side. Our natural distress, the visits of the neighbours, the arranging of the funeral, and all the work of the inn to be carried on in the meanwhile kept me so busy that I had scarcely time to think of the captain, far less to be afraid of him.
He got downstairs next morning, to be sure, and had his meals as usual, though he ate little and had more, I am afraid, than his usual supply of rum, for he helped himself out of the bar, scowling and blowing through his nose, and no one dared to cross him. On the night before the funeral he was as drunk as ever; and it was shocking, in that house of mourning, to hear him singing away at his ugly old sea-song; but weak as he was, we were all in the fear of death for him, and the doctor was suddenly taken up with a case many miles away and was never near the house after my father’s death. I have said the captain was weak, and indeed he seemed rather to grow weaker than regain his strength. He clambered up and down stairs, and went from the parlour to the bar and back again, and sometimes put his nose out of doors to smell the sea, holding on to the walls as he went for support and breathing hard and fast like a man on a steep mountain. He never particularly addressed me, and it is my belief he had as good as forgotten his confidences; but his temper was more flighty, and allowing for his bodily weakness, more violent than ever. He had an alarming way now when he was drunk of drawing his cutlass and laying it bare before him on the table. But with all that, he minded people less and seemed shut up in his own thoughts and rather wandering. Once, for instance, to our extreme wonder, he piped up to a different air, a kind of country love-song that he must have learned in his youth before he had begun to follow the sea.

He still had his old habit of keeping his cutlass on the table beside him when he sat drinking, and he would lay his hand upon it and look at the people who came in and out, as if he dared them to speak or to interfere. The people about the inn were terrified of him, and even my mother, who was a brave woman, was sometimes cowed by his violence and his oaths.

The night before the funeral he was as drunk as ever, and sang his old sea-song with a kind of fury, and in a voice that made the house ring again. It was a scandal to our mourning, and my mother and I were both shocked and frightened. The doctor was away at a great distance, and could not be called in to help us. The captain grew worse and worse, and I began to think he would die on our hands.

He seemed to forget all about me, and never addressed me again, except in the way of ordering more rum. His temper grew blacker and blacker, and he would sometimes sit for hours together, mumbling to himself and staring at the fire. Once, to our great surprise, he began to sing a very different kind of song—a gentle, old-fashioned country love-song, such as I had never heard before, and which, I suppose, he must have learned in his youth, before he took to the sea.

I remembered the good Squire and the Doctor, and poor old Tom Redruth, and I felt very miserable and lonely. But I was not going to give up without a struggle. I watched the shore, and presently I saw a little opening among the trees, and a white rock shining in the moonlight. I made up my mind to try to reach it, and I set to work with all my strength to paddle the coracle in that direction. It was hard work, and I made very little progress, but I kept on, and at last I found myself close to the shore. I could see the sand and the rocks, and the dark shapes of the trees. I was just about to spring out and drag the coracle up the beach, when I heard a sound that made my heart stand still. So things passed until, the day after the funeral, and about three o’clock of a bitter, foggy, frosty afternoon, I was standing at the door for a moment, full of sad thoughts about my father, when I saw someone drawing slowly near along the road. He was plainly blind, for he tapped before him with a stick and wore a great green shade over his eyes and nose; and he was hunched, as if with age or weakness, and wore a huge old tattered sea-cloak with a hood that made him appear positively deformed. I never saw in my life a more dreadful-looking figure. He stopped a little from the inn, and raising his voice in an odd sing-song, addressed the air in front of him, “Will any kind friend inform a poor blind man, who has lost the precious sight of his eyes in the gracious defence of his native country, England—and God bless King George!—where or in what part of this country he may now be?”
“You are at the Admiral Benbow, Black Hill Cove, my good man,” said I.
“I hear a voice,” said he, “a young voice. Will you give me your hand, my kind young friend, and lead me in?”

events.title: The Blind Man Delivers the Black Spot
detailed_summary: Jim extends his hand, which the blind man, despite his soft-spoken demeanor, seizes with an iron grip that alarms Jim.
The blind man then yanks Jim towards him and curtly orders Jim to take him to the captain.

Jim hesitates, expressing concern for the blind man's own safety, alluding to the captain's unstable condition and his habit of keeping a drawn cutlass, but the blind man contemptuously dismisses this and physically compels Jim by painfully twisting his arm, threatening to break it.
The sheer cruelty, coldness, and ugliness in the blind man's voice intimidate Jim more profoundly than the physical pain, leading to his immediate compliance.
Jim guides the blind man, who maintains a tight grip and leans heavily on him, into the inn and towards the parlor where the captain is sitting in a rum-induced stupor.

As they approach, the blind man commands Jim to announce his arrival by shouting, 'Here's a friend for you, Bill,' reinforcing the order with another painful twitch that nearly makes Jim faint from terror, overriding his fear of the captain.
With a trembling voice, Jim opens the parlor door and utters the prescribed words.

The captain looks up, and the sight of the blind visitor instantly dispels his drunkenness, leaving him staring with an expression not of fear, but of profound, deathly illness; he attempts to stand but appears too weak.
The blind man orders Bill to remain seated, asserting he can detect any movement despite his blindness, then directs Jim to take the captain's left hand and present it to his own right hand.
Both Jim and the captain obey precisely; Jim observes the blind man transfer a small object from the hand holding his stick into the captain's palm, which the captain immediately closes upon it.

Declaring his 'business' concluded, the blind man abruptly releases Jim and, with astonishing speed and agility, darts out of the parlor and onto the road, his tapping stick quickly fading into the distance as Jim remains frozen in place.

events.text_segment:
I held out my hand, and the horrible, soft-spoken, eyeless creature gripped it in a moment like a vise. I was so much startled that I struggled to withdraw, but the blind man pulled me close up to him with a single action of his arm.
“Now, boy,” he said, “take me in to the captain.”
“Sir,” said I, “upon my word I dare not.”
“Oh,” he sneered, “that’s it! Take me in straight or I’ll break your arm.”
And he gave it, as he spoke, a wrench that made me cry out.
“Sir,” said I, “it is for yourself I mean. The captain is not what he used to be. He sits with a drawn cutlass. Another gentleman—”
“Come, now, march,” interrupted he; and I never heard a voice so cruel, and cold, and ugly as that blind man’s. It cowed me more than the pain, and I began to obey him at once, walking straight in at the door and towards the parlour, where our sick old buccaneer was sitting, dazed with rum. The blind man clung close to me, holding me in one iron fist and leaning almost more of his weight on me than I could carry. “Lead me straight up to him, and when I’m in view, cry out, ‘Here’s a friend for you, Bill.’ If you don’t, I’ll do this,” and with that he gave me a twitch that I thought would have made me faint. Between this and that, I was so utterly terrified of the blind beggar that I forgot my terror of the captain, and as I opened the parlour door, cried out the words he had ordered in a trembling voice.
The poor captain raised his eyes, and at one look the rum went out of him and left him staring sober. The expression of his face was not so much of terror as of mortal sickness. He made a movement to rise, but I do not believe he had enough force left in his body.
“Now, Bill, sit where you are,” said the beggar. “If I can’t see, I can hear a finger stirring. Business is business. Hold out your left hand. Boy, take his left hand by the wrist and bring it near to my right.”
We both obeyed him to the letter, and I saw him pass something from the hollow of the hand that held his stick into the palm of the captain’s, which closed upon it instantly.
“And now that’s done,” said the blind man; and at the words he suddenly left hold of me, and with incredible accuracy and nimbleness, skipped out of the parlour and into the road, where, as I still stood motionless, I could hear his stick go tap-tap-tapping into the distance.

"Upstairs," I replied, my voice trembling. "In his room."

"Take me to him."

I led the way up the narrow staircase, the boards creaking beneath our feet. At the door to the captain's room, I hesitated, but the blind man pushed me forward. I knocked softly, and after a moment's pause, the captain's gruff voice answered.

"Who is it?"

"It's me, sir—Jim Hawkins. There's a man to see you."

There was a moment of silence, then the sound of the captain rising from his bed. He opened the door, and his eyes widened as he saw the blind man standing there.

"Now, Bill," the blind man said, "sit down. I've a message for you."

The captain backed away, his face ashen, and sank into a chair. The blind man reached into his coat and produced a small piece of paper, which he pressed into the captain's hand.

"You know what that means, Bill," he said. "You have till ten tonight."

With that, the blind man turned and left the room, his cane tapping on the floor. I stood frozen, watching as the captain stared at the paper in his hand, his face contorted with fear. The die was cast, and I knew that nothing would ever be the same again.

events.title: The Captain's Reaction to the Black Spot and Sudden Death
detailed_summary: A period of stunned silence follows before Jim and the captain appear to recover their faculties almost simultaneously.
Jim lets go of the captain's wrist, which he had unconsciously continued to hold.
The captain retracts his hand and peers intently at its palm.
He cries out, 'Ten o’clock! Six hours. We’ll do them yet,' and then, with a burst of energy, springs to his feet.

However, this sudden movement is his last; he immediately staggers, clutches at his throat, sways precariously for an instant, and then, with a strange sound, collapses face-first onto the floor from his full height.
Jim rushes to his side, calling out for his mother, but their efforts are futile.
The captain has died instantly from what Jim understands to be a 'thundering apoplexy.'
Jim reflects on the curious fact that, despite never having liked the captain (though he had recently begun to feel some pity for him), he is overcome by a flood of tears at the sight of his death.
He notes that this is the second death he has witnessed in his young life, and the grief from the first (his father's recent passing) is still acutely painful.

events.text_segment:
The hamlet lay not many hundred yards away, though out of view, on the other side of the next cove; and what greatly encouraged me, it was in an opposite direction from that whence the blind man had made his appearance and whither he had presumably returned. We were not many minutes on the road, though we sometimes stopped to lay hold of each other and hearken. But there was no unusual sound—nothing but the low wash of the ripple and the croaking of the inmates of the wood.
It was already candle-light when we reached the hamlet, and I shall never forget how much I was cheered to see the yellow shine in doors and windows; but that, as it proved, was the best of the help we were likely to get in that quarter. For—you would have thought men would have been ashamed of themselves—no soul would consent to return with us to the Admiral Benbow. The more we told of our troubles, the more—man, woman, and child—they clung to the shelter of their houses. The name of Captain Flint, though it was strange to me, was well enough known to some there and carried a great weight of terror. Some of the men who had been to field-work on the far side of the Admiral Benbow remembered, besides, to have seen several strangers on the road, and taking them to be smugglers, to have bolted away; and one at least had seen a little lugger in what we called Kitt’s Hole. For that matter, anyone who was a comrade of the captain’s was enough to frighten them to death. And the short and the long of the matter was, that while we could get several who were willing enough to ride to Dr. Livesey’s, which lay in another direction, not one would help us to defend the inn.

They say cowardice is infectious; but then argument is, on the other hand, a great emboldener; and so when each had said his say, my mother made them a speech. She would not, she declared, lose money that belonged to her fatherless boy; “If none of the rest of you dare,” she said, “Jim and I dare. Back we will go, the way we came, and small thanks to you big, hulking, chicken-hearted men. We’ll have that chest open, if we die for it. And I’ll thank you for that bag, Mrs. Crossley, to bring back our lawful money in.”
Of course I said I would go with my mother, and of course they all cried out at our foolhardiness, but even then not a man would go along with us. All they would do was to give me a loaded pistol lest we were attacked, and to promise to have horses ready saddled in case we were pursued on our return, while one lad was to ride forward to the doctor’s in search of armed assistance.

My heart was beating finely when we two set forth in the cold night upon this dangerous venture. A full moon was beginning to rise and peered redly through the upper edges of the fog, and this increased our haste, for it was plain, before we came forth again, that all would be as bright as day, and our departure exposed to the eyes of any watchers. We slipped along the hedges, noiseless and swift, nor did we see or hear anything to increase our terrors, till, to our relief, the door of the Admiral Benbow had closed behind us.
I slipped the bolt at once, and we stood and panted for a moment in the dark, alone in the house with the dead captain’s body. Then my mother got a candle in the bar, and holding each other’s hands, we advanced into the parlour. He lay as we had left him, on his back, with his eyes open and one arm stretched out.
“Draw down the blind, Jim,” whispered my mother; “they might come and watch outside. And now,” said she when I had done so, “we have to get the key off that; and who’s to touch it, I should like to know!” and she gave a kind of sob as she said the words.
I went down on my knees at once. On the floor close to his hand there was a little round of paper, blackened on the one side. I could not doubt that this was the black spot; and taking it up, I found written on the other side, in a very good, clear hand, this short message: “You have till ten tonight.”
“He had till ten, Mother,” said I; and just as I said it, our old clock began striking. This sudden noise startled us shockingly; but the news was good, for it was only six.

It was like any other seaman’s chest on the outside, the initial “B” burned on the top of it with a hot iron, and the corners somewhat smashed and broken as by long, rough usage.
“Give me the key,” said my mother; and though the lock was very stiff, she had turned it and thrown back the lid in a twinkling.

Under that, the miscellany began—a quadrant, a tin canikin, several sticks of tobacco, two brace of very handsome pistols, a piece of bar silver, an old Spanish watch and some other trinkets of little value and mostly of foreign make, a pair of compasses mounted with brass, and five or six curious West Indian shells. I have often wondered since why he should have carried about these shells with him in his wandering, guilty, and hunted life.
In the meantime, we had found nothing of any value but the silver and the trinkets, and neither of these were in our way. Underneath there was an old boat-cloak, whitened with sea-salt on many a harbour-bar. My mother pulled it up with impatience, and there lay before us, the last things in the chest, a bundle tied up in oilcloth, and looking like papers, and a canvas bag that gave forth, at a touch, the jingle of gold.

events.text_segment:
“I’ll show these rogues that I’m an honest woman,” said my mother. “I’ll have my dues, and not a farthing over. Hold Mrs. Crossley’s bag.” And she began to count over the amount of the captain’s score from the sailor’s bag into the one that I was holding.
It was a long, difficult business, for the coins were of all countries and sizes—doubloons, and louis d’ors, and guineas, and pieces of eight, and I know not what besides, all shaken together at random. The guineas, too, were about the scarcest, and it was with these only that my mother knew how to make her count.
When we were about half-way through, I suddenly put my hand upon her arm, for I had heard in the silent frosty air a sound that brought my heart into my mouth—the tap-tapping of the blind man’s stick upon the frozen road. It drew nearer and nearer, while we sat holding our breath. Then it struck sharp on the inn door, and then we could hear the handle being turned and the bolt rattling as the wretched being tried to enter; and then there was a long time of silence both within and without. At last the tapping recommenced, and, to our indescribable joy and gratitude, died slowly away again until it ceased to be heard.

events.title: Interrupted Reckoning and Urgent Decision to Flee
detailed_summary: Deeply unsettled by the blind man's attempt to enter and certain that the bolted door would seem suspicious and attract more trouble, Jim implores his mother to take all the money and leave immediately.
Despite her fear, Jim's mother obstinately refuses to take a fraction more than what she believes is rightfully due to her, and she is equally unwilling to be content with less.
She argues that it is still a long way from seven o'clock, implying they have time before the "ten o'night" deadline, and insists on her rights as she knows them.
Their argument is abruptly cut short by the sound of a little low whistle from a good way off upon the hill, a clear signal of approaching danger that is more than enough for both of them.
His mother jumps to her feet, quickly deciding she will take the amount she has already counted.
Jim, seizing the opportunity, picks up the oilskin packet of papers, stating he will take it to "square the count," meaning it will serve as the remainder of their due.

events.text_segment:
“Mother,” said I, “take the whole and let’s be going,” for I was sure the bolted door must have seemed suspicious and would bring the whole hornet’s nest about our ears, though how thankful I was that I had bolted it, none could tell who had never met that terrible blind man.
But my mother, frightened as she was, would not consent to take a fraction more than was due to her and was obstinately unwilling to be content with less. It was not yet seven, she said, by a long way; she knew her rights and she would have them; and she was still arguing with me when a little low whistle sounded a good way off upon the hill. That was enough, and more than enough, for both of us.
“I’ll take what I have,” she said, jumping to her feet.
“And I’ll take this to square the count,” said I, picking up the oilskin packet.

But my mother, frightened as she was, would not consent to take a fraction more than was her due. She was obstinate. She said she would have her rights and she would have nothing but her rights, and she was still so much the mistress of herself that she counted out the money to the last farthing and put the rest back in the chest. I caught up the oilskin packet, which I had taken from the chest, to make up our due, and together we slipped out of the house as quietly as we could.

events.title: The Escape, Pursuit, and Mother's Collapse
detailed_summary: They immediately begin their retreat, groping their way downstairs in the dark, leaving the candle by the now-empty chest, and in the next moment, they had opened the door and were in full flight.

Their departure is none too soon, as the fog is rapidly dispersing, and the moon already shines clearly on the high ground, though a thin veil of fog still conceals the immediate area around the tavern door and the first steps of their escape.
They realize that less than halfway to the hamlet, beyond the bottom of the hill, they will be exposed in the moonlight.
Their peril is compounded by the sound of several people running, coming from the direction of their pursuers.
Looking back, they see a light tossing to and fro and rapidly advancing, indicating one of the newcomers carried a lantern.
Suddenly, Jim's mother cries out that she is about to faint, a development Jim thinks will be the end for them both.
Jim internally curses the cowardice of the neighbors and blames his mother's honesty, greed, past foolhardiness, and present weakness.
By good fortune, they are at a little bridge; Jim manages to help his mother, who is tottering, to the edge of the bank.
She gives a sigh and collapses onto his shoulder.
Unsure how he found the strength, and fearing he did so roughly, Jim manages to drag her down the bank and a little way under the arch of the bridge.

He cannot move her further because the bridge is too low, allowing him only to crawl beneath it, so they are forced to remain there, his mother almost entirely exposed and both of them within earshot of the inn.

events.text_segment:
Next moment we were both groping downstairs, leaving the candle by the empty chest; and the next we had opened the door and were in full retreat. We had not started a moment too soon. The fog was rapidly dispersing; already the moon shone quite clear on the high ground on either side; and it was only in the exact bottom of the dell and round the tavern door that a thin veil still hung unbroken to conceal the first steps of our escape. Far less than half-way to the hamlet, very little beyond the bottom of the hill, we must come forth into the moonlight. Nor was this all, for the sound of several footsteps running came already to our ears, and as we looked back in their direction, a light tossing to and fro and still rapidly advancing showed that one of the newcomers carried a lantern.
“My dear,” said my mother suddenly, “take the money and run on. I am going to faint.”
This was certainly the end for both of us, I thought. How I cursed the cowardice of the neighbours; how I blamed my poor mother for her honesty and her greed, for her past foolhardiness and present weakness! We were just at the little bridge, by good fortune; and I helped her, tottering as she was, to the edge of the bank, where, sure enough, she gave a sigh and fell on my shoulder. I do not know how I found the strength to do it at all, and I am afraid it was roughly done, but I managed to drag her down the bank and a little way under the arch. Farther I could not move her, for the bridge was too low to let me do more than crawl below it. So there we had to stay—my mother almost entirely exposed and both of us within earshot of the inn.

We must have made a noise, for, just as we got to the door, out came the moon, and the fog lifted, and we saw the high road before us, white with moonlight, and the village beyond, black and still. Not a soul was stirring. We could see the lighted windows of the inn, and hear the voices of the men inside. But we dared not go back. My mother was nearly fainting, and I was at my wit's end. I saw that we must get away at once, or we were lost. I looked back. The door of the inn stood open, and a light was moving to and fro inside. The bridge was low, and we could not stand upright, but the spot was at least concealed from above, though we were both of us within earshot of the inn, and my mother, almost entirely exposed, lay as if dead in my arms.

We did not pause to look behind us, but made straight for the road, where we could see the moonlight glimmering on the wet surface. The night air was sharp and cold, and the wind, which had lulled for a moment, now rose again with a mournful sound among the trees. At last we reached the inn, and, bursting in, found my mother seated by the fire, pale and trembling, but safe. "That must be the thing they were after," he said. "We must keep it safe until we can get it to the proper authorities."

I put the packet in my pocket, and, feeling somewhat reassured by the presence of so many friends, sat down by the fire to recover my breath. But my mind was still full of the horrors of the night, and I could not help but wonder what new dangers might be in store for us before our adventure was over.

chapters.chapter_title: V-The Last of the Blind Man

events.title: The Buccaneers' Arrival and Initial Search of the Inn
detailed_summary: Driven by curiosity over fear, the narrator returns to a vantage point overlooking the inn.
He witnesses the arrival of seven or eight men, led by one with a lantern, running erratically.
He recognizes the blind beggar, Pew, among them, confirmed by his voice.
Pew orders his men to break down the inn door.
The men rush the Admiral Benbow, but pause, surprised to find the door already open.
Pew, impatient and enraged, shouts for them to enter immediately.
Four or five men go inside, while two stay with Pew on the road.
A cry of surprise is heard from the inn, followed by the announcement that Bill is deceased.
Pew angrily commands some to search the body and others to go upstairs for the chest.
The narrator hears the men rushing up the stairs.
Sounds of astonishment follow, the captain's room window is forcefully opened, breaking glass, and a man addresses Pew from above.
The man reports that others have preceded them and searched the chest thoroughly.
