events.title: Standoff in the Shrouds and Hands' Apparent Surrender
detailed_summary: Holding a pistol in each hand, Jim warned Hands not to take another step or he would shoot, adding with a chuckle, "Dead men don’t bite, you know."
Hands halted immediately, his face showing the slow, laborious effort of his thoughts, which made Jim laugh in his newfound security.
After a moment, Hands spoke, his expression still one of extreme perplexity, having to remove the dagger from his mouth to talk.
He stated that he and Jim were in a difficult situation ('fouled') and would have to come to an agreement ('sign articles').
Hands admitted that Jim would have been defeated if not for the ship's sudden lurch, attributing his failure to bad luck.
He concluded that he would have to surrender ('strike'), which he found humiliating for a master mariner to do before a young ship's boy like Jim.

Then, with a pistol in either hand, I addressed him.
“One more step, Mr. Hands,” said I, “and I’ll blow your brains out! Dead men don’t bite, you know,” I added with a chuckle.
He stopped instantly. I could see by the working of his face that he was trying to think, and the process was so slow and laborious that, in my new-found security, I laughed aloud. At last, with a swallow or two, he spoke, his face still wearing the same expression of extreme perplexity. In order to speak he had to take the dagger from his mouth, but in all else he remained unmoved.
“Jim,” says he, “I reckon we’re fouled, you and me, and we’ll have to sign articles. I’d have had you but for that there lurch, but I don’t have no luck, not I; and I reckon I’ll have to strike, which comes hard, you see, for a master mariner to a ship’s younker like you, Jim.”

events.title: Hands' Deceptive Attack and His Fatal Plunge
detailed_summary: Jim was complacently listening to Hands' words, feeling quite pleased with himself.
Suddenly, Hands swiftly brought his right hand back over his shoulder.
Something flew through the air like an arrow, and Jim felt a blow followed by a sharp pain; he found himself pinned by the shoulder to the mast by the dirk.
In the shock and agony of the moment, Jim's actions were almost involuntary and certainly unintentional; both his pistols discharged and fell from his grasp.
The pistols were not the only things to fall; with a choked cry, Hands lost his grip on the shrouds and plummeted headfirst into the water below.

events.title: Israel Hands's Demise and Jim's Traumatic Reaction
detailed_summary: From his position on the cross-trees, Jim observes Israel Hands, who was closer to the ship, fall into the water between him and the bulwarks.
Hands briefly resurfaces amidst foam and blood before sinking permanently.
Jim can see Hands's body settled on the bright sand beneath the ship, with fish darting past it and the water's movement creating an illusion of him trying to rise.
He confirms Hands is dead, both shot and drowned, ironically becoming food for fish in the very spot he intended to kill Jim.
A wave of nausea, faintness, and terror overwhelms Jim almost immediately after confirming Hands's death.

The physical pain from the dirk pinning his shoulder and his bleeding chest are less distressing to him than the profound horror of potentially falling from the cross-trees into the water beside Hands's corpse.
He grips the cross-trees until his nails ache and shuts his eyes against the perceived danger, eventually calming down and regaining his composure.

events.text_segment:
Owing to the cant of the vessel, the masts hung far out over the water, and from my perch on the cross-trees I had nothing below me but the surface of the bay. Hands, who was not so far up, was in consequence nearer to the ship and fell between me and the bulwarks. He rose once to the surface in a lather of foam and blood and then sank again for good. As the water settled, I could see him lying huddled together on the clean, bright sand in the shadow of the vessel’s sides. A fish or two whipped past his body. Sometimes, by the quivering of the water, he appeared to move a little, as if he were trying to rise. But he was dead enough, for all that, being both shot and drowned, and was food for fish in the very place where he had designed my slaughter.
I was no sooner certain of this than I began to feel sick, faint, and terrified. The hot blood was running over my back and chest. The dirk, where it had pinned my shoulder to the mast, seemed to burn like a hot iron; yet it was not so much these real sufferings that distressed me, for these, it seemed to me, I could bear without a murmur; it was the horror I had upon my mind of falling from the cross-trees into that still green water, beside the body of the coxswain.
I clung with both hands till my nails ached, and I shut my eyes as if to cover up the peril. Gradually my mind came back again, my pulses quieted down to a more natural time, and I was once more in possession of myself.

It was a strange and chilling sight, for the hull of the Hispaniola, canted over as she was, seemed almost to float upon her side, her deck sloping steeply down towards the water, and her rigging trailing in the gentle swell. The sun was now high, and the light danced upon the ripples, throwing reflections up onto the weathered wood and the tangled ropes. I clung to the cross-trees, my heart thumping, for the height was dizzying and the ship’s position precarious. Below, the shore was quiet, the trees standing motionless in the heat, and not a soul was to be seen.

events.title: Self-Liberation and Disposal of O'Brien's Body
detailed_summary: Jim initially considers removing the dirk pinning his shoulder to the mast but lacks the nerve or strength, stopping with a shudder.
This very shudder, ironically, dislodges the knife, which had only superficially caught his skin.
Although the bleeding intensifies, Jim feels a renewed sense of control, now only attached to the mast by his coat and shirt.
He tears himself free with a sudden jerk and climbs back to the deck using the starboard shrouds, avoiding the port shrouds from which Hands had fallen.
Jim attends to his wound below deck, finding it painful and bleeding but neither deep nor dangerously impairing his arm's movement.
Considering the ship his own, he decides to remove its last remaining passenger, the deceased O'Brien.
He finds O'Brien's body slumped against the bulwarks, appearing like a grotesque puppet, and, having grown accustomed to such grim sights, disposes of it.
Jim takes O'Brien by the waist and heaves him overboard, where he lands with a splash, his red cap floating on the surface.
He then observes O'Brien's body lying beside Israel Hands's on the seabed, with fish swimming around both corpses.

events.text_segment:
It was my first thought to pluck forth the dirk, but either it stuck too hard or my nerve failed me, and I desisted with a violent shudder. Oddly enough, that very shudder did the business. The knife, in fact, had come the nearest in the world to missing me altogether; it held me by a mere pinch of skin, and this the shudder tore away. The blood ran down the faster, to be sure, but I was my own master again and only tacked to the mast by my coat and shirt.
These last I broke through with a sudden jerk, and then regained the deck by the starboard shrouds. For nothing in the world would I have again ventured, shaken as I was, upon the overhanging port shrouds from which Israel had so lately fallen.
I went below and did what I could for my wound; it pained me a good deal and still bled freely, but it was neither deep nor dangerous, nor did it greatly gall me when I used my arm. Then I looked around me, and as the ship was now, in a sense, my own, I began to think of clearing it from its last passenger—the dead man, O’Brien.
He had pitched, as I have said, against the bulwarks, where he lay like some horrible, ungainly sort of puppet, life-size, indeed, but how different from life’s colour or life’s comeliness! In that position I could easily have my way with him, and as the habit of tragical adventures had worn off almost all my terror for the dead, I took him by the waist as if he had been a sack of bran and with one good heave, tumbled him overboard. He went in with a sounding plunge; the red cap came off and remained floating on the surface; and as soon as the splash subsided, I could see him and Israel lying side by side, both wavering with the tremulous movement of the water. O’Brien, though still quite a young man, was very bald. There he lay, with that bald head across the knees of the man who had killed him and the quick fishes steering to and fro over both.

events.title: Securing and Abandoning the Hispaniola
detailed_summary: Jim finds himself the sole occupant of the Hispaniola as the tide begins to ebb and the setting sun casts long shadows across the deck.
The rising evening breeze causes the ship's rigging to hum and the sails to flap, signaling potential trouble for the vessel.
He successfully lowers and secures the jibs on deck but faces a greater challenge with the mainsail.
The ship's tilt has caused the boom to swing outboard, with part of the sail submerged, making it dangerous.
Despite his apprehension about the heavy strain, Jim uses his knife to cut the halyards, causing the mainsail's peak to drop and the canvas to spread across the water.
He is unable to manage the downhaul, leaving the Hispaniola to rely on luck, much like himself.
As the anchorage becomes fully shadowed, with the last sunbeams highlighting the wreck, the air grows chilly and the tide swiftly flows seaward, causing the schooner to list further.
Jim scrambles to the bow, assesses the water depth, and, holding the cut hawser for safety, drops overboard into waist-deep water.
He wades ashore onto firm sand with a sense of relief and accomplishment, leaving the Hispaniola on its side with its mainsail adrift as the sun sets completely.

events.text_segment:
I was now alone upon the ship; the tide had just turned. The sun was within so few degrees of setting that already the shadow of the pines upon the western shore began to reach right across the anchorage and fall in patterns on the deck. The evening breeze had sprung up, and though it was well warded off by the hill with the two peaks upon the east, the cordage had begun to sing a little softly to itself and the idle sails to rattle to and fro.
I began to see a danger to the ship. The jibs I speedily doused and brought tumbling to the deck, but the main-sail was a harder matter. Of course, when the schooner canted over, the boom had swung out-board, and the cap of it and a foot or two of sail hung even under water. I thought this made it still more dangerous; yet the strain was so heavy that I half feared to meddle. At last I got my knife and cut the halyards. The peak dropped instantly, a great belly of loose canvas floated broad upon the water, and since, pull as I liked, I could not budge the downhall, that was the extent of what I could accomplish. For the rest, the Hispaniola must trust to luck, like myself.
By this time the whole anchorage had fallen into shadow—the last rays, I remember, falling through a glade of the wood and shining bright as jewels on the flowery mantle of the wreck. It began to be chill; the tide was rapidly fleeting seaward, the schooner settling more and more on her beam-ends.
I scrambled forward and looked over. It seemed shallow enough, and holding the cut hawser in both hands for a last security, I let myself drop softly overboard. The water scarcely reached my waist; the sand was firm and covered with ripple marks, and I waded ashore in great spirits, leaving the Hispaniola on her side, with her main-sail trailing wide upon the surface of the bay. About the same time, the sun went fairly down and the breeze whistled low in the dusk among the tossing pines.

events.title: Triumphant Return Ashore and a Puzzling Distant Fire
detailed_summary: Jim feels a profound sense of relief and pride at having escaped the sea and, more importantly, having reclaimed the Hispaniola from the pirates, making it ready for his own party.

His immediate desire is to return to the stockade and share news of his achievements, believing the recapture of the ship will excuse his unauthorized absence, perhaps even impressing Captain Smollett.
Filled with high spirits, he starts his journey towards the blockhouse and his companions.
He recalls that one of the rivers flowing into the anchorage originates from the two-peaked hill to his left and decides to follow its course upstream while it is still small.
The terrain is relatively open, and by following the lower hill spurs, he soon rounds the hill and wades across the stream.
This path brings him close to the area where he first encountered Ben Gunn, the maroon, prompting him to proceed with greater caution and vigilance.
As dusk settles, he notices a flickering glow against the sky near the cleft between the two peaks, which he assumes is Ben Gunn's campfire.
He privately wonders at Ben Gunn's apparent lack of caution, considering that the light from such a large fire could easily be spotted by Silver and his men camped nearby.

At least, and at last, I was off the sea, nor had I returned thence empty-handed. There lay the schooner, clear at last from buccaneers and ready for our own men to board and get to sea again. I had nothing nearer my fancy than to get home to the stockade and boast of my achievements. Possibly I might be blamed a bit for my truantry, but the recapture of the Hispaniola was a clenching answer, and I hoped that even Captain Smollett would confess I had not lost my time.
So thinking, and in famous spirits, I began to set my face homeward for the block house and my companions. I remembered that the most easterly of the rivers which drain into Captain Kidd’s anchorage ran from the two-peaked hill upon my left, and I bent my course in that direction that I might pass the stream while it was small. The wood was pretty open, and keeping along the lower spurs, I had soon turned the corner of that hill, and not long after waded to the mid-calf across the watercourse.
This brought me near to where I had encountered Ben Gunn, the maroon; and I walked more circumspectly, keeping an eye on every side. The dusk had come nigh hand completely, and as I opened out the cleft between the two peaks, I became aware of a wavering glow against the sky, where, as I judged, the man of the island was cooking his supper before a roaring fire. And yet I wondered, in my heart, that he should show himself so careless. For if I could see this radiance, might it not reach the eyes of Silver himself where he camped upon the shore among the marshes?

events.title: Navigating by Moonlight and Approaching a Mysterious Glow
detailed_summary: As the night grows darker, Jim struggles to maintain his course, with landmarks like the double hill and the Spy-glass becoming indistinct and stars providing little light.
He finds himself stumbling through bushes and into sandy pits in the low-lying terrain.
Suddenly, a brightness appears around him; he looks up to see pale moonlight illuminating the summit of the Spy-glass.
Shortly thereafter, he observes the moon itself, large and silvery, rising behind the trees.
With the moonlight to guide him, Jim moves more quickly over the remaining distance to the stockade, alternating between walking and running in his eagerness.
However, as he enters the grove leading to the stockade, he prudently slows his pace and proceeds with caution, wary of being accidentally shot by his own companions.
The rising moon casts patches of light through the trees, and directly ahead, Jim notices a glow of a different color—red and hot, resembling the embers of a dying bonfire.
He is completely baffled by the nature of this mysterious red glow.

events.title: Investigating the Eerily Silent Stockade
detailed_summary: Jim finally arrives at the edge of the clearing where the stockade is located.
He observes that the western part of the clearing is bathed in moonlight, while the rest, including the blockhouse itself, remains in deep shadow interspersed with silvery light streaks.
On the far side of the house, an enormous fire has burned down to clear embers, emitting a steady, red glow that contrasts sharply with the soft moonlight.
There is no sign of movement or any sound apart from the sighing of the breeze.
A mix of profound wonder and a touch of terror fills Jim, as building such large fires was contrary to their usual practice under Captain Smollett's orders to conserve firewood.
He begins to fear that something unfortunate occurred during his time away from the stockade.
Maintaining stealth, Jim circles around to the eastern side of the stockade, staying within the shadows, and finds a suitably dark spot to cross the defensive palisade.

events.text_segment:
At last I came right down upon the borders of the clearing. The western end was already steeped in moonshine; the rest, and the block house itself, still lay in a black shadow chequered with long silvery streaks of light. On the other side of the house an immense fire had burned itself into clear embers and shed a steady, red reverberation, contrasted strongly with the mellow paleness of the moon. There was not a soul stirring nor a sound beside the noises of the breeze.
I stopped, with much wonder in my heart, and perhaps a little terror also. It had not been our way to build great fires; we were, indeed, by the captain’s orders, somewhat niggardly of firewood, and I began to fear that something had gone wrong while I was absent.
I stole round by the eastern end, keeping close in shadow, and at a convenient place, where the darkness was thickest, crossed the palisade.

events.title: False Reassurance and Parrot's Startling Alarm
detailed_summary: To ensure his safety and assess the situation, Jim cautiously crawls on his hands and knees towards a corner of the blockhouse.
His anxiety lessens significantly when he hears the sound of loud, peaceful snoring from within, which he interprets as his friends sleeping soundly.
He notes the irony that the watch's reassuring call of "All's well" had never sounded more welcome, despite the current circumstances.

He reflects on the poor quality of their watch, thinking that if Silver and his men had been approaching, they would have been easily overcome, and he blames himself for leaving his companions so vulnerable, especially with the captain injured.
Reaching the door, Jim stands up and enters the completely dark interior, unable to discern anything visually.
He hears the continuous drone of snores and a faint, inexplicable flickering or pecking sound.
He silently chuckles at the thought of lying down in his usual spot and enjoying his friends' surprise when they discover him in the morning.
His foot then makes contact with something soft – a sleeper's leg – causing the person to groan but not awaken.
Suddenly, a shrill voice erupts from the darkness, repeatedly squawking "Pieces of eight!", identified by Jim as Silver's parrot, Captain Flint.
Jim realizes the pecking sound he heard was the parrot, who, unlike the human occupants, was alert and now announcing his arrival.

events.text_segment:
To make assurance surer, I got upon my hands and knees and crawled, without a sound, towards the corner of the house. As I drew nearer, my heart was suddenly and greatly lightened. It is not a pleasant noise in itself, and I have often complained of it at other times, but just then it was like music to hear my friends snoring together so loud and peaceful in their sleep. The sea-cry of the watch, that beautiful “All’s well,” never fell more reassuringly on my ear.
In the meantime, there was no doubt of one thing; they kept an infamous bad watch. If it had been Silver and his lads that were now creeping in on them, not a soul would have seen daybreak. That was what it was, thought I, to have the captain wounded; and again I blamed myself sharply for leaving them in that danger with so few to mount guard.
By this time I had got to the door and stood up. All was dark within, so that I could distinguish nothing by the eye. As for sounds, there was the steady drone of the snorers and a small occasional noise, a flickering or pecking that I could in no way account for.
With my arms before me I walked steadily in. I should lie down in my own place (I thought with a silent chuckle) and enjoy their faces when they found me in the morning.
My foot struck something yielding—it was a sleeper’s leg; and he turned and groaned, but without awaking.
And then, all of a sudden, a shrill voice broke forth out of the darkness:
“Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight!” and so forth, without pause or change, like the clacking of a tiny mill.
Silver’s green parrot, Captain Flint! It was she whom I had heard pecking at a piece of bark; it was she, keeping better watch than any human being, who thus announced my arrival with her wearisome refrain.

As I drew nearer, the voices grew more distinct, and I could make out the rough, grumbling tones of the men within. My heart beat thickly in my chest, but I pressed on, inch by inch, until I could peer around the corner and see the flicker of lamplight through a chink in the boards. There, huddled together, sat the pirates, their faces drawn and anxious, their hands restless on the butts of their pistols. Silver, with his crutch laid across his knees, was speaking in a low, urgent whisper, his one good eye glinting in the dim light.

This second person seizes him firmly, preventing his escape.
Once Jim's capture is confirmed, Silver issues an order to someone named Dick, instructing him to bring a torch.
One of the men promptly exits the log-house and returns shortly thereafter carrying a lit brand, illuminating the scene and revealing Jim's captors.

events.title: Jim's Shocking Discovery and Capture in the Blockhouse
detailed_summary: Jim Hawkins enters the blockhouse to find it occupied by pirates, realizing his worst fears.
He observes the familiar stores but sees no prisoners, leading him to believe his friends have perished, a thought that causes him great distress.
Six buccaneers are present; five are on their feet, appearing disoriented from being awakened from a drunken sleep, while the sixth is pale and wounded, likely the man shot during the earlier attack.
Long John Silver's parrot is on his shoulder, and Silver himself appears more somber and stern than usual, his fine clothes now damaged and dirty.
Silver greets Jim with a semblance of friendliness, acknowledging Jim's unexpected arrival.
He sits and prepares his pipe, instructing one pirate, Dick, for a light and telling the others they don't need to stand for Jim.
Silver expresses his surprise at Jim's appearance, admitting Jim's cleverness has surpassed his expectations.
Jim remains silent, positioned against the wall, facing Silver with outward courage but internal despair.

The red glare of the torch, lighting up the interior of the block house, showed me the worst of my apprehensions realized. The pirates were in possession of the house and stores: there was the cask of cognac, there were the pork and bread, as before, and what tenfold increased my horror, not a sign of any prisoner. I could only judge that all had perished, and my heart smote me sorely that I had not been there to perish with them.
There were six of the buccaneers, all told; not another man was left alive. Five of them were on their feet, flushed and swollen, suddenly called out of the first sleep of drunkenness. The sixth had only risen upon his elbow; he was deadly pale, and the blood-stained bandage round his head told that he had recently been wounded, and still more recently dressed. I remembered the man who had been shot and had run back among the woods in the great attack, and doubted not that this was he.
The parrot sat, preening her plumage, on Long John’s shoulder. He himself, I thought, looked somewhat paler and more stern than I was used to. He still wore the fine broadcloth suit in which he had fulfilled his mission, but it was bitterly the worse for wear, daubed with clay and torn with the sharp briers of the wood.
“So,” said he, “here’s Jim Hawkins, shiver my timbers! Dropped in, like, eh? Well, come, I take that friendly.”
And thereupon he sat down across the brandy cask and began to fill a pipe.
“Give me a loan of the link, Dick,” said he; and then, when he had a good light, “That’ll do, lad,” he added; “stick the glim in the wood heap; and you, gentlemen, bring yourselves to! You needn’t stand up for Mr. Hawkins; he’ll excuse you, you may lay to that. And so, Jim”—stopping the tobacco—“here you were, and quite a pleasant surprise for poor old John. I see you were smart when first I set my eyes on you, but this here gets away from me clean, it do.”
To all this, as may be well supposed, I made no answer. They had set me with my back against the wall, and I stood there, looking Silver in the face, pluckily enough, I hope, to all outward appearance, but with black despair in my heart.

events.title: Silver's Persuasion and Revelation of the Doctor's Bargain
detailed_summary: Silver, after a few puffs of his pipe, begins to address Jim, stating his intention to give Jim a piece of his mind.
He claims he has always liked Jim for his spirit, seeing him as a younger version of himself, and had always wanted Jim to join his crew.
Silver asserts that Captain Smollett, though a fine seaman, is too strict, and implies Jim should distance himself from him.
He tells Jim that Doctor Livesey considers him an 'ungrateful scamp' and that Jim's former companions will not accept him back.
Silver concludes that Jim's only viable option, short of forming his own lonely crew, is to join him.
Jim feels a sense of relief upon learning his friends are alive, more so than distress, despite partially believing Silver's claim about their anger towards him for his desertion.
Silver continues, emphasizing Jim's current predicament of being in their hands, but professes a preference for argument over threats.
He presents Jim with a supposed choice: join them if he likes the service, or freely refuse, claiming no fairer offer could be made.
Jim, with a trembling voice, asks if he is truly to answer, feeling the immense pressure and threat of death despite Silver's sneering words.
Silver reassures Jim that no one is rushing him, mockingly stating that they enjoy his company.
Growing bolder, Jim demands to know the current situation, why the pirates are in the blockhouse, and the whereabouts of his friends.
One pirate growls in response, suggesting that knowing 'wot's wot' would make one lucky, but Silver sharply silences him.
Silver then explains to Jim that Doctor Livesey had arrived with a flag of truce the previous morning, informing them the ship was gone.
He admits they might have been drinking and were unaware of the ship's departure until they looked.
Silver recounts bargaining with the doctor, resulting in the pirates gaining the blockhouse, stores, and firewood, while Jim's friends 'tramped' off to an unknown location.

He further specifies that Jim was not part of this treaty, quoting the doctor as saying there were four to leave (one wounded) and that he didn't know or much care about Jim's whereabouts, calling him a 'confound him' and stating they were 'about sick of him'.

events.text_segment:
Silver took a whiff or two of his pipe with great composure and then ran on again.
“Now, you see, Jim, so be as you are here,” says he, “I’ll give you a piece of my mind. I’ve always liked you, I have, for a lad of spirit, and the picter of my own self when I was young and handsome. I always wanted you to jine and take your share, and die a gentleman, and now, my cock, you’ve got to. Cap’n Smollett’s a fine seaman, as I’ll own up to any day, but stiff on discipline. ‘Dooty is dooty,’ says he, and right he is. Just you keep clear of the cap’n. The doctor himself is gone dead again’ you—‘ungrateful scamp’ was what he said; and the short and the long of the whole story is about here: you can’t go back to your own lot, for they won’t have you; and without you start a third ship’s company all by yourself, which might be lonely, you’ll have to jine with Cap’n Silver.”
So far so good. My friends, then, were still alive, and though I partly believed the truth of Silver’s statement, that the cabin party were incensed at me for my desertion, I was more relieved than distressed by what I heard.
“I don’t say nothing as to your being in our hands,” continued Silver, “though there you are, and you may lay to it. I’m all for argyment; I never seen good come out o’ threatening. If you like the service, well, you’ll jine; and if you don’t, Jim, why, you’re free to answer no—free and welcome, shipmate; and if fairer can be said by mortal seaman, shiver my sides!”
“Am I to answer, then?” I asked with a very tremulous voice. Through all this sneering talk, I was made to feel the threat of death that overhung me, and my cheeks burned and my heart beat painfully in my breast.
“Lad,” said Silver, “no one’s a-pressing of you. Take your bearings. None of us won’t hurry you, mate; time goes so pleasant in your company, you see.”
“Well,” says I, growing a bit bolder, “if I’m to choose, I declare I have a right to know what’s what, and why you’re here, and where my friends are.”
“Wot’s wot?” repeated one of the buccaneers in a deep growl. “Ah, he’d be a lucky one as knowed that!”
“You’ll perhaps batten down your hatches till you’re spoke to, my friend,” cried Silver truculently to this speaker. And then, in his first gracious tones, he replied to me, “Yesterday morning, Mr. Hawkins,” said he, “in the dog-watch, down came Doctor Livesey with a flag of truce. Says he, ‘Cap’n Silver, you’re sold out. Ship’s gone.’ Well, maybe we’d been taking a glass, and a song to help it round. I won’t say no. Leastways, none of us had looked out. We looked out, and by thunder, the old ship was gone! I never seen a pack o’ fools look fishier; and you may lay to that, if I tells you that looked the fishiest. ‘Well,’ says the doctor, ‘let’s bargain.’ We bargained, him and I, and here we are: stores, brandy, block house, the firewood you was thoughtful enough to cut, and in a manner of speaking, the whole blessed boat, from cross-trees to kelson. As for them, they’ve tramped; I don’t know where’s they are.”
He drew again quietly at his pipe.
“And lest you should take it into that head of yours,” he went on, “that you was included in the treaty, here’s the last word that was said: ‘How many are you,’ says I, ‘to leave?’ ‘Four,’ says he; ‘four, and one of us wounded. As for that boy, I don’t know where he is, confound him,’ says he, ‘nor I don’t much care. We’re about sick of him.’ These was his words.”

He took another puff at his pipe and looked out over the camp, where the men were moving about, some cleaning their muskets, others talking in low voices. Silver seemed to sense my unease, for he clapped me on the shoulder and laughed softly.

With that, he rose and stretched his legs, knocking the ashes from his pipe. The men called out to him, and he limped away, leaving me alone by the fire, my mind in a whirl of fear and hope. I watched him go, the crutch swinging under his arm, his broad back turned to me, and I wondered what the next day would bring.

The night fell quickly, and the camp grew quiet. I lay down on my blanket, but sleep would not come. The voices of the men, the crackle of the fire, and the distant cry of a night bird all seemed to blend into a single, uneasy sound. I thought of my friends in the stockade, of the treasure hidden somewhere on the island, and of the strange alliance I had made with the most dangerous man among the pirates. At last, worn out with anxiety and excitement, I fell into a troubled sleep, dreaming of gold and blood and the sea.

events.text_segment:
“Is that all?” I asked.
“Well, it’s all that you’re to hear, my son,” returned Silver.
“And now I am to choose?”
“And now you are to choose, and you may lay to that,” said Silver.
“Well,” said I, “I am not such a fool but I know pretty well what I have to look for. Let the worst come to the worst, it’s little I care. I’ve seen too many die since I fell in with you. But there’s a thing or two I have to tell you,” I said, and by this time I was quite excited; “and the first is this: here you are, in a bad way—ship lost, treasure lost, men lost, your whole business gone to wreck; and if you want to know who did it—it was I! I was in the apple barrel the night we sighted land, and I heard you, John, and you, Dick Johnson, and Hands, who is now at the bottom of the sea, and told every word you said before the hour was out. And as for the schooner, it was I who cut her cable, and it was I that killed the men you had aboard of her, and it was I who brought her where you’ll never see her more, not one of you. The laugh’s on my side; I’ve had the top of this business from the first; I no more fear you than I fear a fly. Kill me, if you please, or spare me. But one thing I’ll say, and no more; if you spare me, bygones are bygones, and when you fellows are in court for piracy, I’ll save you all I can. It is for you to choose. Kill another and do yourselves no good, or spare me and keep a witness to save you from the gallows.”
I stopped, for, I tell you, I was out of breath, and to my wonder, not a man of them moved, but all sat staring at me like as many sheep. And while they were still staring, I broke out again, “And now, Mr. Silver,” I said, “I believe you’re the best man here, and if things go to the worst, I’ll take it kind of you to let the doctor know the way I took it.”
“I’ll bear it in mind,” said Silver with an accent so curious that I could not, for the life of me, decide whether he were laughing at my request or had been favourably affected by my courage.

events.text_segment:
“I’ll put one to that,” cried the old mahogany-faced seaman—Morgan by name—whom I had seen in Long John’s public-house upon the quays of Bristol. “It was him that knowed Black Dog.”
“Well, and see here,” added the sea-cook. “I’ll put another again to that, by thunder! For it was this same boy that faked the chart from Billy Bones. First and last, we’ve split upon Jim Hawkins!”
“Then here goes!” said Morgan with an oath.
And he sprang up, drawing his knife as if he had been twenty.
“Avast, there!” cried Silver. “Who are you, Tom Morgan? Maybe you thought you was cap’n here, perhaps. By the powers, but I’ll teach you better! Cross me, and you’ll go where many a good man’s gone before you, first and last, these thirty year back—some to the yard-arm, shiver my timbers, and some by the board, and all to feed the fishes. There’s never a man looked me between the eyes and seen a good day a’terwards, Tom Morgan, you may lay to that.”
Morgan paused, but a hoarse murmur rose from the others.
“Tom’s right,” said one.
“I stood hazing long enough from one,” added another. “I’ll be hanged if I’ll be hazed by you, John Silver.”
“Did any of you gentlemen want to have it out with me?” roared Silver, bending far forward from his position on the keg, with his pipe still glowing in his right hand. “Put a name on what you’re at; you ain’t dumb, I reckon. Him that wants shall get it. Have I lived this many years, and a son of a rum puncheon cock his hat athwart my hawse at the latter end of it? You know the way; you’re all gentlemen o’ fortune, by your account. Well, I’m ready. Take a cutlass, him that dares, and I’ll see the colour of his inside, crutch and all, before that pipe’s empty.”
Not a man stirred; not a man answered.
“That’s your sort, is it?” he added, returning his pipe to his mouth. “Well, you’re a gay lot to look at, anyway. Not much worth to fight, you ain’t. P’r’aps you can understand King George’s English. I’m cap’n here by ’lection. I’m cap’n here because I’m the best man by a long sea-mile. You won’t fight, as gentlemen o’ fortune should; then, by thunder, you’ll obey, and you may lay to it! I like that boy, now; I never seen a better boy than that. He’s more a man than any pair of rats of you in this here house, and what I say is this: let me see him that’ll lay a hand on him—that’s what I say, and you may lay to it.”
There was a long pause after this. I stood straight up against the wall, my heart still going like a sledge-hammer, but with a ray of hope now shining in my bosom. Silver leant back against the wall, his arms crossed, his pipe in the corner of his mouth, as calm as though he had been in church; yet his eye kept wandering furtively, and he kept the tail of it on his unruly followers. They, on their part, drew gradually together towards the far end of the block house, and the low hiss of their whispering sounded in my ear continuously, like a stream. One after another, they would look up, and the red light of the torch would fall for a second on their nervous faces; but it was not towards me, it was towards Silver that they turned their eyes.

A murmur of agreement ran around the table. I watched from my hiding place, scarcely daring to breathe. The talk of treasure and treachery sent a chill down my spine, but I could not tear myself away.

Long John Silver, who had been listening with a sly smile, now leaned forward, his good leg stretched out before him, his crutch resting against the bench. “Now, mates,” he said, his voice smooth as oil, “there’s no call for quarrelling. The men grumbled, but none dared contradict him. Silver’s authority was plain, and even the roughest of the crew seemed to respect—or fear—him.

“Jim,” he said suddenly, turning his gaze on me, “you’ve been quiet, lad. What do you make of all this?”

I started, caught off guard by his question. “I—I don’t know, sir,” I stammered. “It all seems very dangerous.”

Silver laughed, a great booming sound that filled the cabin. “Dangerous, he says! Well, so it is, boy, so it is. But that’s the life of a sailor, eh, lads?”

A chorus of “Aye!” and “That’s right!” answered him.

“But mind you,” Silver went on, his tone turning serious, “there’s danger, and then there’s foolishness. We must keep our wits about us, or we’ll end up like those poor devils Flint left behind.”

The mention of Flint’s victims cast a pall over the gathering. For a moment, no one spoke. Then Morgan raised his mug. “To Flint!” he cried. “And to the gold!”

The others echoed the toast, though some did so with less enthusiasm. I could see the fear in their eyes, the knowledge that they were playing a deadly game.

As the night wore on, the talk turned to plans and promises, to whispered threats and uneasy alliances. I listened, my heart pounding, knowing that the fate of all aboard the Hispaniola hung in the balance. The treasure was close, but so too was danger, and I wondered if any of us would live to see the sun rise on Treasure Island.

“You seem to have a lot to say,” remarked Silver, spitting far into the air. “Pipe up and let me hear it, or lay to.”
“Ax your pardon, sir,” returned one of the men; “you’re pretty free with some of the rules; maybe you’ll kindly keep an eye upon the rest. This crew’s dissatisfied; this crew don’t vally bullying a marlin-spike; this crew has its rights like other crews, I’ll make so free as that; and by your own rules, I take it we can talk together. I ax your pardon, sir, acknowledging you for to be capting at this present; but I claim my right, and steps outside for a council.”
And with an elaborate sea-salute, this fellow, a long, ill-looking, yellow-eyed man of five and thirty, stepped coolly towards the door and disappeared out of the house. One after another the rest followed his example, each making a salute as he passed, each adding some apology. “According to rules,” said one. “Forecastle council,” said Morgan. And so with one remark or another all marched out and left Silver and me alone with the torch.
The sea-cook instantly removed his pipe.
“Now, look you here, Jim Hawkins,” he said in a steady whisper that was no more than audible, “you’re within half a plank of death, and what’s a long sight worse, of torture. They’re going to throw me off. But, you mark, I stand by you through thick and thin. I didn’t mean to; no, not till you spoke up. I was about desperate to lose that much blunt, and be hanged into the bargain. But I see you was the right sort. I says to myself, you stand by Hawkins, John, and Hawkins’ll stand by you. You’re his last card, and by the living thunder, John, he’s yours! Back to back, says I. You save your witness, and he’ll save your neck!”
I began dimly to understand.
“You mean all’s lost?” I asked.
“Aye, by gum, I do!” he answered. “Ship gone, neck gone—that’s the size of it. Once I looked into that bay, Jim Hawkins, and seen no schooner—well, I’m tough, but I gave out. As for that lot and their council, mark me, they’re outright fools and cowards. I’ll save your life—if so be as I can—from them. But, see here, Jim—tit for tat—you save Long John from swinging.”
I was bewildered; it seemed a thing so hopeless he was asking—he, the old buccaneer, the ringleader throughout.
“What I can do, that I’ll do,” I said.
“It’s a bargain!” cried Long John. “You speak up plucky, and by thunder, I’ve a chance!”
He hobbled to the torch, where it stood propped among the firewood, and took a fresh light to his pipe.
“Understand me, Jim,” he said, returning. “I’ve a head on my shoulders, I have. I’m on squire’s side now. I know you’ve got that ship safe somewheres. How you done it, I don’t know, but safe it is. I guess Hands and O’Brien turned soft. I never much believed in neither of them. Now you mark me. I ask no questions, nor I won’t let others. I know when a game’s up, I do; and I know a lad that’s staunch. Ah, you that’s young—you and me might have done a power of good together!”
He drew some cognac from the cask into a tin cannikin.
“Will you taste, messmate?” he asked; and when I had refused: “Well, I’ll take a dram myself, Jim,” said he. “I need a caulker, for there’s trouble on hand. And talking o’ trouble, why did that doctor give me the chart, Jim?”
My face expressed a wonder so unaffected that he saw the needlessness of further questions.
“Ah, well, he did, though,” said he. “And there’s something under that, no doubt—something, surely, under that, Jim—bad or good.”
And he took another swallow of the brandy, shaking his great fair head like a man who looks forward to the worst.

The sea-cook instantly removed his pipe. “Now, look you here, Jim Hawkins,” he said in a steady whisper, “you’re within half a plank of death, and, what’s a long sight worse, of torture. They’re going to depose me; but, Jim, I stand by you through thick and thin. I didn’t mean to; no, not till you spoke up, but I see you’re the right sort. I was desperate—on my own account and for the sake of the treasure and the gallows. But you stood firm. I’ll stand by you, and you’ll stand by me. That’s my last card, and it’s yours too, mate. Save me, and I’ll save you.”

I was bewildered; it seemed a hopeless thing, this last request of Silver’s. I could not find a word to answer.

“Is it all lost?” I asked.

“Ship gone, neck gone, that’s the size of it. When I saw the schooner was gone, I gave up. As for them, they’re fools and cowards. I’ll save your life, if so be as I can, from them. But, Jim, you’ll bear a hand for me, won’t you? If I get out of this alive, you’ll testify for me, and save me from the gallows?”

I said I would do what I could.

“It’s a bargain!” cried Long John. “You’re a plucky lad, and I’m with you. You’ve got the ship, I’ll wager, though I don’t know how. Hands and O’Brien, I suppose, weren’t as good as you on the board. But I’ll not ask, and I’ll see no one else does. You and me might have done a power of good together, Jim.”

He relit his pipe at the torch. Then he went to a corner, drew a bottle of cognac from the cask, and filled a tin pannikin. “Will you have any?” he asked. I declined.

He drank it off, shaking his head. “I need a stiffener,” he said. “There’s trouble coming. Now, why did Doctor Livesey give me the chart, Jim?”

I could only stare in surprise, and he saw it.

“Ah!” he said, “that’s a puzzler, that is. But it means something—something good or bad.”

He took another drink, shaking his head, as if he had his doubts, and seemed to settle himself to wait for what might befall.

I shook my head. “Not unless you promise me safe passage. I won’t be part of your mutiny.”

There was a tense silence. Silver tapped his pipe against his wooden leg. “You drive a hard bargain, Jim Hawkins. But you’re a smart lad. Smarter than most here, I’ll wager.”

One of the men, Morgan, growled, “Let’s just make him talk, Silver. We don’t need his permission.”

Silver raised a hand. “Easy, mate. The boy’s got spirit. And spirit’s worth something, in my book.” He turned to me again. “So, Jim, what do you say? You help us, and we’ll see you safe. Cross my heart.”

I hesitated. I could feel the sweat trickling down my back. “I can’t betray my friends,” I said at last. “But I won’t stand in your way, either. Let me go, and I’ll keep your secrets.”

Silver laughed, a harsh, barking sound. “You’re a cool one, Jim. But I can’t let you go just yet. Not till we have the treasure.”

The men grumbled, but Silver’s authority held them in check. He leaned closer, his voice dropping to a whisper. “Listen, lad. Things are coming to a head. There’s no turning back now. You stick with me, and I’ll see you through. But cross me, and—” He drew a finger across his throat.

I shivered, but met his gaze. “I understand.”

Silver straightened, addressing the crew. “The boy stays with us. He’s our insurance. Anyone got a problem with that?”

There was some muttering, but no one challenged him. Silver nodded, satisfied. “Good. Now, let’s get some rest. Tomorrow, we go after the treasure.”

The men dispersed, some casting dark looks my way. Silver lingered, watching me with a calculating eye. “You’re a brave lad, Jim. I’ll give you that. But don’t push your luck.”

He turned away, leaving me alone with my thoughts. I sat down on a coil of rope, my heart pounding. I had bought myself a little time, but I knew the danger was far from over. The night was thick with the scent of salt and tar, and the distant cry of a gull echoed over the water. I wondered what tomorrow would bring, and whether I would live to see the sun rise again.

As the fire died down and the men settled into uneasy sleep, I resolved to keep my wits about me. Silver was cunning, but I had my own share of cleverness. events.text_segment:
The council of buccaneers had lasted some time, when one of them re-entered the house, and with a repetition of the same salute, which had in my eyes an ironical air, begged for a moment’s loan of the torch. Silver briefly agreed, and this emissary retired again, leaving us together in the dark.
“There’s a breeze coming, Jim,” said Silver, who had by this time adopted quite a friendly and familiar tone.
I turned to the loophole nearest me and looked out. The embers of the great fire had so far burned themselves out and now glowed so low and duskily that I understood why these conspirators desired a torch. About half-way down the slope to the stockade, they were collected in a group; one held the light, another was on his knees in their midst, and I saw the blade of an open knife shine in his hand with varying colours in the moon and torchlight. The rest were all somewhat stooping, as though watching the manoeuvres of this last. I could just make out that he had a book as well as a knife in his hand, and was still wondering how anything so incongruous had come in their possession when the kneeling figure rose once more to his feet and the whole party began to move together towards the house.
“Here they come,” said I; and I returned to my former position, for it seemed beneath my dignity that they should find me watching them.

events.title: Silver Condemns the Sacrilegious Black Spot
detailed_summary: Silver examined the item handed to him.
He identified it as the black spot, as he had suspected.
He questioned where they got the paper, then exclaimed with alarm that it was cut from a Bible, deeming this act unlucky and foolish.
Morgan affirmed this, recalling he had warned against such an action, predicting no good would come of it.
Silver declared that they had sealed their fate and would all likely hang now.
He asked which 'soft-headed lubber' had possessed a Bible.
One of the men revealed it was Dick.
Silver retorted that Dick should then prepare for prayers, as his luck had run out.

The sea-cook looked at what had been given him.
“The black spot! I thought so,” he observed. “Where might you have got the paper? Why, hillo! Look here, now; this ain’t lucky! You’ve gone and cut this out of a Bible. What fool’s cut a Bible?”

events.title: George Merry Presents the Charges Against Silver
detailed_summary: A tall man with yellow eyes, George Merry, interrupted Silver forcefully.
He stated that the crew, in a formal council and as per their duty, had presented Silver with the black spot.
Merry instructed Silver to turn the paper over, again as per duty, and read what was written before continuing to speak.
Silver thanked George, sarcastically complimenting his briskness for business and knowledge of the rules.
He read the message: 'Deposed'.
Silver then mocked the handwriting, likening it to print and questioning if it was George's, insinuating George was aiming to be captain.
He asked for the torch again, claiming his pipe wouldn't draw.
George retorted that Silver was no longer fooling the crew, acknowledging Silver's reputation as a 'funny man' but asserting his time was over and that he should step down to vote.
Silver contemptuously replied that he knew the rules better, or at least as well as they did, and would wait as their captain until they presented their grievances and he had replied.
He declared their black spot held no value until that process was complete.
George assured Silver they were adhering to procedures and then listed their accusations:
First, Silver had made a mess of the entire cruise.
Second, Silver had allowed their enemies to leave the stockade for no apparent benefit, questioning why they wanted to leave but emphasizing that they clearly did.
Third, Silver had forbidden them from attacking the enemy group during their march.
George accused Silver of intending to 'play booty' (deceive them or act for his own gain).
Fourth, he cited the presence of Jim, 'this here boy', as a grievance.
Silver quietly asked if that was the extent of their complaints.
George vehemently replied that it was more than sufficient, predicting they would all be hanged due to Silver's incompetence.

events.text_segment:
But here the long man with the yellow eyes struck in.
“Belay that talk, John Silver,” he said. “This crew has tipped you the black spot in full council, as in dooty bound; just you turn it over, as in dooty bound, and see what’s wrote there. Then you can talk.”
“Thanky, George,” replied the sea-cook. “You always was brisk for business, and has the rules by heart, George, as I’m pleased to see. Well, what is it, anyway? Ah! ‘Deposed’—that’s it, is it? Very pretty wrote, to be sure; like print, I swear. Your hand o’ write, George? Why, you was gettin’ quite a leadin’ man in this here crew. You’ll be cap’n next, I shouldn’t wonder. Just oblige me with that torch again, will you? This pipe don’t draw.”
“Come, now,” said George, “you don’t fool this crew no more. You’re a funny man, by your account; but you’re over now, and you’ll maybe step down off that barrel and help vote.”
“I thought you said you knowed the rules,” returned Silver contemptuously. “Leastways, if you don’t, I do; and I wait here—and I’m still your cap’n, mind—till you outs with your grievances and I reply; in the meantime, your black spot ain’t worth a biscuit. After that, we’ll see.”
“Oh,” replied George, “you don’t be under no kind of apprehension; we’re all square, we are. First, you’ve made a hash of this cruise—you’ll be a bold man to say no to that. Second, you let the enemy out o’ this here trap for nothing. Why did they want out? I dunno, but it’s pretty plain they wanted it. Third, you wouldn’t let us go at them upon the march. Oh, we see through you, John Silver; you want to play booty, that’s what’s wrong with you. And then, fourth, there’s this here boy.”
“Is that all?” asked Silver quietly.
“Enough, too,” retorted George. “We’ll all swing and sun-dry for your bungling.”

events.title: Silver's Spirited Defense Against the Accusations
detailed_summary: Silver announced he would address their four points sequentially.
Regarding the first charge of ruining the cruise, he reminded them of his original plan, asserting that if they had followed it, they would all be safely aboard the Hispaniola with the treasure.

He then turned the blame on them, specifically Anderson, Hands, and George Merry, for crossing him, forcing his hand as the lawful captain, and giving him the black spot on the day they landed, thus starting the 'dance' leading to their current predicament.
He likened their situation to awaiting execution at Execution Dock in London.
Silver paused, and Jim observed that his words visibly affected George and his companions.
Wiping sweat from his brow after his vehement speech, Silver dismissed the first charge, expressing his disgust at having to speak to men with neither sense nor memory.
Morgan encouraged him to continue addressing the others.
Silver sarcastically referred to the others as a 'nice lot' and elaborated on how badly the cruise was bungled, emphasizing their proximity to the gallows.
He painted a vivid picture of them being hanged in chains, with seamen identifying their corpses.
He reiterated that their dire situation was thanks to Merry, Hands, Anderson, and other 'ruination fools'.

Addressing the fourth point about Jim, Silver declared the boy was a hostage, questioning if they would waste such an asset, suggesting Jim might be their last chance for survival and that he would not kill him.

Regarding the third point (not attacking the enemy on the march), Silver highlighted the strategic advantage of having a 'real college doctor' (Dr. Livesey) available to treat their injuries and illnesses, citing John's head injury and George Merry's recent ague.
He then revealed the crucial information that a 'consort' (another ship or rescue party) was expected, implying the hostage would be vital then.

Finally, addressing the second point about why he made a bargain (letting the Doctor's party leave the stockade), he reminded them that they had come to him on their knees, downhearted and starving, begging him to make that deal.

events.text_segment:
“Well now, look here, I’ll answer these four p’ints; one after another I’ll answer ’em. I made a hash o’ this cruise, did I? Well now, you all know what I wanted, and you all know if that had been done that we’d ’a been aboard the Hispaniola this night as ever was, every man of us alive, and fit, and full of good plum-duff, and the treasure in the hold of her, by thunder! Well, who crossed me? Who forced my hand, as was the lawful cap’n? Who tipped me the black spot the day we landed and began this dance? Ah, it’s a fine dance—I’m with you there—and looks mighty like a hornpipe in a rope’s end at Execution Dock by London town, it does. But who done it? Why, it was Anderson, and Hands, and you, George Merry! And you’re the last above board of that same meddling crew; and you have the Davy Jones’s insolence to up and stand for cap’n over me—you, that sank the lot of us! By the powers! But this tops the stiffest yarn to nothing.”
Silver paused, and I could see by the faces of George and his late comrades that these words had not been said in vain.
“That’s for number one,” cried the accused, wiping the sweat from his brow, for he had been talking with a vehemence that shook the house. “Why, I give you my word, I’m sick to speak to you. You’ve neither sense nor memory, and I leave it to fancy where your mothers was that let you come to sea. Sea! Gentlemen o’ fortune! I reckon tailors is your trade.”
“Go on, John,” said Morgan. “Speak up to the others.”
“Ah, the others!” returned John. “They’re a nice lot, ain’t they? You say this cruise is bungled. Ah! By gum, if you could understand how bad it’s bungled, you would see! We’re that near the gibbet that my neck’s stiff with thinking on it. You’ve seen ’em, maybe, hanged in chains, birds about ’em, seamen p’inting ’em out as they go down with the tide. ‘Who’s that?’ says one. ‘That! Why, that’s John Silver. I knowed him well,’ says another. And you can hear the chains a-jangle as you go about and reach for the other buoy. Now, that’s about where we are, every mother’s son of us, thanks to him, and Hands, and Anderson, and other ruination fools of you. And if you want to know about number four, and that boy, why, shiver my timbers, isn’t he a hostage? Are we a-going to waste a hostage? No, not us; he might be our last chance, and I shouldn’t wonder. Kill that boy? Not me, mates! And number three? Ah, well, there’s a deal to say to number three. Maybe you don’t count it nothing to have a real college doctor to see you every day—you, John, with your head broke—or you, George Merry, that had the ague shakes upon you not six hours agone, and has your eyes the colour of lemon peel to this same moment on the clock? And maybe, perhaps, you didn’t know there was a consort coming either? But there is, and not so long till then; and we’ll see who’ll be glad to have a hostage when it comes to that. And as for number two, and why I made a bargain—well, you came crawling on your knees to me to make it—on your knees you came, you was that downhearted—and you’d have starved too if I hadn’t—but that’s a trifle! You look there—that’s why!”

I’d had enough of the sea for a while, and I wanted to be ashore, with a roof over my head and a fire at my feet. That’s why I came here, and that’s the truth of it.

Third, you ask about that old sea-chest of mine. There’s nothing in it but my own property—some clothes, a few books, and a bit of money I’ve saved. There’s nothing in it to concern anyone but myself, and I’d thank you to leave it be. I keep it locked for my own reasons, and I don’t want anyone poking about in my affairs. That’s the third point, and I hope you’ll respect my wishes.

Fourth and last, you want to know if I’ve seen any strange men about, or if I’m expecting company. Well, I’ll not deny that I’ve had my share of acquaintances in my time, and not all of them were the sort you’d want to meet in a dark alley. But I’ve no dealings with any of them now, and I’m not expecting anyone. If any man comes asking for me, you can tell him I’m not at home, and that’s the end of it.

Now, I’ve answered your four points, fair and square, and I hope you’ll let me be. I’m a man who likes his peace and quiet, and I don’t want any trouble. I pay my way, and I keep to myself. That’s all I ask in return. If you can grant me that, we’ll get along fine. If not, I’ll be on my way, and you’ll never see me again.

With that, the old sailor sat back in his chair, his eyes fixed on the fire, and his hands folded in his lap. There was a silence in the room, broken only by the crackling of the logs and the distant sound of the wind outside. I looked at my mother, and she looked at me, and neither of us knew quite what to say. The man’s words had been plain enough, but there was something in his manner that made me uneasy—a sense of danger, or of secrets kept just out of sight.

At last, my mother spoke. “Very well, sir,” she said, her voice steady. “You’re welcome to stay, so long as you pay your way and keep the peace. But I’ll not have any trouble in my house, mind you.”

The old sailor nodded, a grim smile on his lips. “You’ll have no trouble from me, ma’am,” he said. “So long as I’m left to myself, I’ll be as quiet as a mouse.”

And with that, the matter was settled—for the time being, at least. But I could not shake the feeling that we had let something dangerous into our home, and that our quiet lives would never be the same again.

events.title: The Treasure Chart Revealed: Silver's Trump Card
detailed_summary: Silver threw a paper onto the floor, which Jim immediately identified as Captain Flint's treasure chart with the three red crosses, the same one he had found earlier.
Jim was completely mystified as to how Dr. Livesey could have given it to Silver.
The appearance of the chart was utterly unbelievable to the surviving mutineers.
They pounced on it like cats on a mouse, snatching it from one another with oaths, cries, and childish laughter, as if they were already handling the gold itself and sailing away safely with it.
One buccaneer confirmed its authenticity, recognizing Flint's mark 'J. F.' and a score with a clove hitch.
George Merry acknowledged its beauty but pragmatically questioned how they could escape with the treasure now that they had no ship.
Silver suddenly rose, supporting himself against the wall, and angrily warned George that one more disrespectful word would lead to a fight.
He retorted that George and the others should be the ones explaining how to get away, as they were responsible for losing the schooner through their interference.
Silver then insulted their intelligence, saying they lacked the ingenuity of a cockroach, but insisted George could and would speak respectfully.

And he cast down upon the floor a paper that I instantly recognized—none other than the chart on yellow paper, with the three red crosses, that I had found in the oilcloth at the bottom of the captain’s chest. Why the doctor had given it to him was more than I could fancy.
But if it were inexplicable to me, the appearance of the chart was incredible to the surviving mutineers. They leaped upon it like cats upon a mouse. It went from hand to hand, one tearing it from another; and by the oaths and the cries and the childish laughter with which they accompanied their examination, you would have thought, not only they were fingering the very gold, but were at sea with it, besides, in safety.
“Yes,” said one, “that’s Flint, sure enough. J. F., and a score below, with a clove hitch to it; so he done ever.”
“Mighty pretty,” said George. “But how are we to get away with it, and us no ship.”
Silver suddenly sprang up, and supporting himself with a hand against the wall: “Now I give you warning, George,” he cried. “One more word of your sauce, and I’ll call you down and fight you. How? Why, how do I know? You had ought to tell me that—you and the rest, that lost me my schooner, with your interference, burn you! But not you, you can’t; you hain’t got the invention of a cockroach. But civil you can speak, and shall, George Merry, you may lay to that.”

events.title: Silver Reasserts Authority and Dismisses the Black Spot
detailed_summary: The old man Morgan declared Silver's demands for respect to be fair.
Silver agreed, contrasting their loss of the ship with his success in finding the treasure, and rhetorically asked who the better man was.
He then dramatically announced his resignation, daring them to elect a new captain as he was done with it.
The buccaneers immediately responded with cries of 'Silver!' and 'Barbecue forever! Barbecue for cap’n!'
Silver acknowledged their change of heart and told George Merry his ambition to be captain would have to wait, adding that it was lucky for George that he wasn't a vengeful person.
He then turned to the matter of the black spot, questioning its current relevance now that Dick had brought bad luck upon himself by defacing a Bible.
Dick, clearly uneasy about the curse, asked if the piece of Bible could still be used for swearing an oath.
Silver derisively replied that a Bible with a piece cut out was useless and no more binding than a book of ballads.
Dick expressed a sort of joyful relief at this news, considering it a worthwhile outcome.

“That’s fair enow,” said the old man Morgan.
“Fair! I reckon so,” said the sea-cook. “You lost the ship; I found the treasure. Who’s the better man at that? And now I resign, by thunder! Elect whom you please to be your cap’n now; I’m done with it.”
“Silver!” they cried. “Barbecue forever! Barbecue for cap’n!”
“So that’s the toon, is it?” cried the cook. “George, I reckon you’ll have to wait another turn, friend; and lucky for you as I’m not a revengeful man. But that was never my way. And now, shipmates, this black spot? ’Tain’t much good now, is it? Dick’s crossed his luck and spoiled his Bible, and that’s about all.”
“It’ll do to kiss the book on still, won’t it?” growled Dick, who was evidently uneasy at the curse he had brought upon himself.
“A Bible with a bit cut out!” returned Silver derisively. “Not it. It don’t bind no more’n a ballad-book.”
“Don’t it, though?” cried Dick with a sort of joy. “Well, I reckon that’s worth having too.”

events.title: The Black Spot's Nature and Jim's Reflections on Silver's Game
detailed_summary: Silver tossed the black spot paper to Jim, calling it a curiosity.

Jim examined it: it was about the size of a crown piece. One side was blank, having been the last leaf of the Bible; the other contained verses from Revelation, including the striking words, 'Without are dogs and murderers.'
The printed side had been blackened with wood ash, which was already smudging Jim's fingers; on the blank side, the single word 'Depposed' had been written with the same ash.
Jim notes that, as he writes his account, the paper is still with him, but almost all traces of the writing have vanished, leaving only a faint scratch.
This concluded the night's dramatic events. After a round of drinks, everyone lay down to sleep.
Silver's only act of vengeance was to assign George Merry to sentinel duty, threatening him with death if he proved unfaithful.

Jim found it difficult to sleep, his mind filled with thoughts of the man he had killed that afternoon, his own dangerous situation, and, most significantly, the remarkable and complex game Silver was playing.
He recognized Silver's efforts to simultaneously keep the mutineers unified while desperately seeking any means to secure his own pardon and save his life.

Despite Silver's profound wickedness, Jim felt a sense of sorrow for him, contemplating the immense dangers surrounding him and the shameful execution that likely awaited him, even as Silver himself slept soundly and snored.

events.text_segment:
“Here, Jim—here’s a cur’osity for you,” said Silver, and he tossed me the paper.
It was around about the size of a crown piece. One side was blank, for it had been the last leaf; the other contained a verse or two of Revelation—these words among the rest, which struck sharply home upon my mind: “Without are dogs and murderers.” The printed side had been blackened with wood ash, which already began to come off and soil my fingers; on the blank side had been written with the same material the one word “Depposed.” I have that curiosity beside me at this moment, but not a trace of writing now remains beyond a single scratch, such as a man might make with his thumb-nail.
That was the end of the night’s business. Soon after, with a drink all round, we lay down to sleep, and the outside of Silver’s vengeance was to put George Merry up for sentinel and threaten him with death if he should prove unfaithful.
It was long ere I could close an eye, and heaven knows I had matter enough for thought in the man whom I had slain that afternoon, in my own most perilous position, and above all, in the remarkable game that I saw Silver now engaged upon—keeping the mutineers together with one hand and grasping with the other after every means, possible and impossible, to make his peace and save his miserable life. He himself slept peacefully and snored aloud, yet my heart was sore for him, wicked as he was, to think on the dark perils that environed and the shameful gibbet that awaited him.

I was wakened—indeed, we were all wakened, for I could see even the sentinel shake himself together from where he had fallen against the door-post—by a clear, hearty voice hailing us from the margin of the wood:
“Block house, ahoy!” it cried. “Here’s the doctor.”
And the doctor it was. Although I was glad to hear the sound, yet my gladness was not without admixture. I remembered with confusion my insubordinate and stealthy conduct, and when I saw where it had brought me—among what companions and surrounded by what dangers—I felt ashamed to look him in the face.
He must have risen in the dark, for the day had hardly come; and when I ran to a loophole and looked out, I saw him standing, like Silver once before, up to the mid-leg in creeping vapour.
“You, doctor! Top o’ the morning to you, sir!” cried Silver, broad awake and beaming with good nature in a moment. “Bright and early, to be sure; and it’s the early bird, as the saying goes, that gets the rations. George, shake up your timbers, son, and help Dr. Livesey over the ship’s side. All a-doin’ well, your patients was—all well and merry.”
So he pattered on, standing on the hilltop with his crutch under his elbow and one hand upon the side of the log-house—quite the old John in voice, manner, and expression.
“We’ve quite a surprise for you too, sir,” he continued. “We’ve a little stranger here—he! he! A noo boarder and lodger, sir, and looking fit and taut as a fiddle; slep’ like a supercargo, he did, right alongside of John—stem to stem we was, all night.”
Dr. Livesey was by this time across the stockade and pretty near the cook, and I could hear the alteration in his voice as he said, “Not Jim?”
“The very same Jim as ever was,” says Silver.
The doctor stopped outright, although he did not speak, and it was some seconds before he seemed able to move on.
“Well, well,” he said at last, “duty first and pleasure afterwards, as you might have said yourself, Silver. Let us overhaul these patients of yours.”
A moment afterwards he had entered the block house and with one grim nod to me proceeded with his work among the sick.

“Block house, ahoy!” it cried. “Here’s the doctor!”

And the doctor it was. Although I had but a glimpse of him, for he was standing almost in the shadow of the trees, I could tell by his voice and bearing that it was Dr. Livesey. He hailed us again, and this time, with a little more authority in his tone, as if he expected an answer.

“Is that you, Jim?” he called.

I started up at the sound of my name, and the others looked at me in surprise. I answered as loudly as I dared, “Yes, sir, it’s me!”

“Are you all safe?” he asked.

“All safe, sir,” I replied, “but we’ve had a rough night.”

“Keep your heads down,” he said, “and don’t show yourselves. I’ll come forward.”

With that, we heard the crackle of twigs as he made his way through the undergrowth, and presently he stepped into the open, his white handkerchief held aloft as a sign of truce. The morning sun was just rising, and the light fell upon his face, making it look pale and anxious. He came up to the stockade and called again, more softly this time, “Let me in, Jim.”

I ran to the door and unbarred it, and the doctor slipped inside, glancing quickly around at the weary faces of my companions. He nodded to each in turn, and then turned to me with a look of relief.

“Thank God you’re safe, boy,” he said. “I’ve been half out of my mind with worry.”

He set down a small bundle he had brought with him and began to examine our wounds and bruises, his hands gentle and sure. The others crowded around him, eager for news and comfort, and for a few moments the fear and tension of the night seemed to lift.

“Have you seen anything of the pirates?” asked the squire.

“Not since last night,” the doctor replied. “But we must be on our guard. They’re still out there, and they’ll not give up easily.”

His words sobered us, and we fell silent, listening to the distant sounds of the forest and the sea, and wondering what the day would bring.

events.text_segment:
He seemed under no apprehension, though he must have known that his life, among these treacherous demons, depended on a hair; and he rattled on to his patients as if he were paying an ordinary professional visit in a quiet English family. His manner, I suppose, reacted on the men, for they behaved to him as if nothing had occurred, as if he were still ship’s doctor and they still faithful hands before the mast.
“You’re doing well, my friend,” he said to the fellow with the bandaged head, “and if ever any person had a close shave, it was you; your head must be as hard as iron. Well, George, how goes it? You’re a pretty colour, certainly; why, your liver, man, is upside down. Did you take that medicine? Did he take that medicine, men?”
“Aye, aye, sir, he took it, sure enough,” returned Morgan.
“Because, you see, since I am mutineers’ doctor, or prison doctor as I prefer to call it,” says Doctor Livesey in his pleasantest way, “I make it a point of honour not to lose a man for King George (God bless him!) and the gallows.”
The rogues looked at each other but swallowed the home-thrust in silence.
“Dick don’t feel well, sir,” said one.
“Don’t he?” replied the doctor. “Well, step up here, Dick, and let me see your tongue. No, I should be surprised if he did! The man’s tongue is fit to frighten the French. Another fever.”
“Ah, there,” said Morgan, “that comed of sp’iling Bibles.”
“That comes—as you call it—of being arrant asses,” retorted the doctor, “and not having sense enough to know honest air from poison, and the dry land from a vile, pestiferous slough. I think it most probable—though of course it’s only an opinion—that you’ll all have the deuce to pay before you get that malaria out of your systems. Camp in a bog, would you? Silver, I’m surprised at you. You’re less of a fool than many, take you all round; but you don’t appear to me to have the rudiments of a notion of the rules of health.
“Well,” he added after he had dosed them round and they had taken his prescriptions, with really laughable humility, more like charity schoolchildren than blood-guilty mutineers and pirates—“well, that’s done for today. And now I should wish to have a talk with that boy, please.”

They all looked at him uneasily, but no one spoke a word.

"Is Dick ill?" he asked.

Dick was indeed very pale and shaky. The doctor looked at his tongue, made a grimace, and pronounced him feverish.

"The swamp, my man, that’s what’s the matter with you. You’ve camped in a place fit for a pest-house, and you’re all going to have the ague; and, as for fever, you’ll have it in your bones before you’re a week older. Why, Silver, you’re not usually so careless."

Morgan mumbled something about Bibles having been misused, but the doctor cut him short.

"Stuff and nonsense!" he said. "You’ve brought this on yourselves by your own folly."

events.title: Silver Negotiates Terms for Jim's Conversation with Dr. Livesey
detailed_summary: Dr. Livesey casually gestures towards Jim while making his request for a private discussion.
George Merry, who is nearby recovering from unpleasant medicine, reacts angrily to the doctor's proposal, shouting "No!" and swearing.
Silver intervenes immediately and forcefully, striking a barrel and roaring for silence, his demeanor described as lion-like, effectively quelling the dissent.
Adopting his usual tone, Silver informs the doctor that he had anticipated such a request, acknowledging the doctor's known fondness for Jim.
He expresses the group's gratitude for the doctor's medical assistance, noting that the men trust him and willingly take his remedies.
Silver then proposes a compromise: Jim must give his word of honor, as a young gentleman, not to attempt an escape.
Jim readily gives the solemn promise required of him.
Silver outlines the arrangement: the doctor will wait outside the stockade, and Silver will bring Jim to the inside of the barrier, allowing them to converse through the wooden spars.
He concludes the exchange with a polite farewell, also sending respects to Squire Trelawney and Captain Smollett.

And he nodded his head in my direction carelessly.
George Merry was at the door, spitting and spluttering over some bad-tasted medicine; but at the first word of the doctor’s proposal he swung round with a deep flush and cried “No!” and swore.
Silver struck the barrel with his open hand.
“Si-lence!” he roared and looked about him positively like a lion. “Doctor,” he went on in his usual tones, “I was a-thinking of that, knowing as how you had a fancy for the boy. We’re all humbly grateful for your kindness, and as you see, puts faith in you and takes the drugs down like that much grog. And I take it I’ve found a way as’ll suit all. Hawkins, will you give me your word of honour as a young gentleman—for a young gentleman you are, although poor born—your word of honour not to slip your cable?”
I readily gave the pledge required.
“Then, doctor,” said Silver, “you just step outside o’ that stockade, and once you’re there I’ll bring the boy down on the inside, and I reckon you can yarn through the spars. Good day to you, sir, and all our dooties to the squire and Cap’n Smollett.”
