events.text_segment:
The explosion of disapproval, which nothing but Silver’s black looks had restrained, broke out immediately the doctor had left the house. Silver was roundly accused of playing double—of trying to make a separate peace for himself, of sacrificing the interests of his accomplices and victims, and, in one word, of the identical, exact thing that he was doing. It seemed to me so obvious, in this case, that I could not imagine how he was to turn their anger. But he was twice the man the rest were, and his last night’s victory had given him a huge preponderance on their minds. He called them all the fools and dolts you can imagine, said it was necessary I should talk to the doctor, fluttered the chart in their faces, asked them if they could afford to break the treaty the very day they were bound a-treasure-hunting.
“No, by thunder!” he cried. “It’s us must break the treaty when the time comes; and till then I’ll gammon that doctor, if I have to ile his boots with brandy.”
And then he bade them get the fire lit, and stalked out upon his crutch, with his hand on my shoulder, leaving them in a disarray, and silenced by his volubility rather than convinced.
“Slow, lad, slow,” he said. “They might round upon us in a twinkle of an eye if we was seen to hurry.”
Very deliberately, then, did we advance across the sand to where the doctor awaited us on the other side of the stockade, and as soon as we were within easy speaking distance Silver stopped.
“You’ll make a note of this here also, doctor,” says he, “and the boy’ll tell you how I saved his life, and were deposed for it too, and you may lay to that. Doctor, when a man’s steering as near the wind as me—playing chuck-farthing with the last breath in his body, like—you wouldn’t think it too much, mayhap, to give him one good word? You’ll please bear in mind it’s not my life only now—it’s that boy’s into the bargain; and you’ll speak me fair, doctor, and give me a bit o’ hope to go on, for the sake of mercy.”
Silver was a changed man once he was out there and had his back to his friends and the block house; his cheeks seemed to have fallen in, his voice trembled; never was a soul more dead in earnest.
“Why, John, you’re not afraid?” asked Dr. Livesey.
“Doctor, I’m no coward; no, not I—not so much!” and he snapped his fingers. “If I was I wouldn’t say it. But I’ll own up fairly, I’ve the shakes upon me for the gallows. You’re a good man and a true; I never seen a better man! And you’ll not forget what I done good, not any more than you’ll forget the bad, I know. And I step aside—see here—and leave you and Jim alone. And you’ll put that down for me too, for it’s a long stretch, is that!”
So saying, he stepped back a little way, till he was out of earshot, and there sat down upon a tree-stump and began to whistle, spinning round now and again upon his seat so as to command a sight, sometimes of me and the doctor and sometimes of his unruly ruffians as they went to and fro in the sand between the fire—which they were busy rekindling—and the house, from which they brought forth pork and bread to make the breakfast.

The men nodded, some reluctantly, others with grim determination. The alliance, such as it was, held—for now. But I could not shake the feeling that the worst was yet to come, and that our troubles were only beginning.

events.title: Jim's Emotional Confession of Guilt and Fear of Torture
detailed_summary: Dr. Livesey addresses Jim with a sorrowful tone, acknowledging that Jim is now facing the consequences of his earlier choices.

While stating he cannot find it in his heart to blame Jim, the doctor firmly asserts that Jim would never have dared to abandon them if Captain Smollett had been healthy, labeling his departure during the captain's illness as an act of cowardice.
Overwhelmed by this judgment, Jim begins to weep.
He implores the doctor to cease his reproaches, admitting he has already blamed himself extensively.
Jim concedes that his life is likely forfeit and that he owes his current survival to Silver's intervention.
He confesses that while he can face the prospect of death, which he feels he might deserve, his paramount fear is being subjected to torture by the pirates.

“So, Jim,” said the doctor sadly, “here you are. As you have brewed, so shall you drink, my boy. Heaven knows, I cannot find it in my heart to blame you, but this much I will say, be it kind or unkind: when Captain Smollett was well, you dared not have gone off; and when he was ill and couldn’t help it, by George, it was downright cowardly!”
I will own that I here began to weep. “Doctor,” I said, “you might spare me. I have blamed myself enough; my life’s forfeit anyway, and I should have been dead by now if Silver hadn’t stood for me; and doctor, believe this, I can die—and I dare say I deserve it—but what I fear is torture. If they come to torture me—”

“Jim,” the doctor interrupted, and his voice was quite changed, “Jim, I can’t have this. Whip over, and we’ll run for it.”
“Doctor,” said I, “I passed my word.”

events.title: Jim's Adventures Recounted; Doctor's Insight and Cryptic Warning to Silver
detailed_summary: Jim quickly recounts the details of his recent daring escapades to Dr. Livesey, who listens to the entire narrative without interruption.
After Jim finishes, Dr. Livesey reflects on the unfolding events, suggesting a kind of destiny at play and emphasizing Jim's crucial role in repeatedly saving their lives.
He reassures Jim that their party will not permit him to lose his own life, especially after all he has done, highlighting that Jim's discovery of Ben Gunn was his most significant contribution.
The mention of Ben Gunn appears to spark a crucial thought or plan in the doctor's mind, as he refers to Ben Gunn as "mischief in person."
Dr. Livesey then calls out to Long John Silver, who approaches them.
The doctor offers Silver a piece of advice, cautioning him against being too eager or rushed in his quest for the treasure.
Silver responds that his pursuit of the treasure is driven by the necessity to save his own life and Jim's.
Dr. Livesey then delivers a more specific and ominous warning, advising Silver to be prepared for significant trouble or danger ("squalls") when he ultimately locates the treasure.

Rapidly I described to him my adventures, and he heard me out in silence.
“There is a kind of fate in this,” he observed when I had done. “Every step, it’s you that saves our lives; and do you suppose by any chance that we are going to let you lose yours? That would be a poor return, my boy. You found out the plot; you found Ben Gunn—the best deed that ever you did, or will do, though you live to ninety. Oh, by Jupiter, and talking of Ben Gunn! Why, this is the mischief in person. Silver!” he cried. “Silver! I’ll give you a piece of advice,” he continued as the cook drew near again; “don’t you be in any great hurry after that treasure.”
“Why, sir, I do my possible, which that ain’t,” said Silver. “I can only, asking your pardon, save my life and the boy’s by seeking for that treasure; and you may lay to that.”
“Well, Silver,” replied the doctor, “if that is so, I’ll go one step further: look out for squalls when you find it.”

events.title: Doctor's Conditional Promise to Silver, Final Advice, and Departure
detailed_summary: Silver expresses his frustration with Dr. Livesey's vague yet ominous warning, deeming it unhelpfully ambiguous.

He complains that he has been following the doctor's instructions (such as surrendering the treasure chart) blindly, without any encouragement or hope offered, and now demands clear information or he will cease cooperating.

Dr. Livesey explains that he is not at liberty to disclose more because the secret he holds is not his own to share, but he is willing to help as much as he possibly can, even risking reprimand from Captain Smollett.

He then offers Silver a significant piece of hope: if they both manage to survive their current dangerous predicament, he will do his absolute best to save Silver's life, provided it does not require him to commit perjury.
Silver is visibly ecstatic upon hearing this promise, declaring that the doctor could not have said anything more reassuring, even if he were Silver's own mother.
The doctor then provides his second piece of advice: Silver must keep Jim constantly by his side, and if he finds himself needing help, he should call out for it.
Dr. Livesey states that he is now departing to actively seek this assistance, implying that his actions will demonstrate the sincerity of his words.
He bids Jim farewell with a handshake through the palisade, gives a nod to Silver, and then quickly walks away into the forest.

events.text_segment:
“Sir,” said Silver, “as between man and man, that’s too much and too little. What you’re after, why you left the block house, why you given me that there chart, I don’t know, now, do I? And yet I done your bidding with my eyes shut and never a word of hope! But no, this here’s too much. If you won’t tell me what you mean plain out, just say so and I’ll leave the helm.”
“No,” said the doctor musingly; “I’ve no right to say more; it’s not my secret, you see, Silver, or, I give you my word, I’d tell it you. But I’ll go as far with you as I dare go, and a step beyond, for I’ll have my wig sorted by the captain or I’m mistaken! And first, I’ll give you a bit of hope; Silver, if we both get alive out of this wolf-trap, I’ll do my best to save you, short of perjury.”
Silver’s face was radiant. “You couldn’t say more, I’m sure, sir, not if you was my mother,” he cried.
“Well, that’s my first concession,” added the doctor. “My second is a piece of advice: keep the boy close beside you, and when you need help, halloo. I’m off to seek it for you, and that itself will show you if I speak at random. Good-bye, Jim.”
And Dr. Livesey shook hands with me through the stockade, nodded to Silver, and set off at a brisk pace into the wood.

events.title: Breakfast and Observations on Pirate Recklessness
detailed_summary: The group is summoned for breakfast, which consists of biscuits and fried preserved meat, cooked over an excessively large and hot fire.
Jim observes the pirates' profound wastefulness, noting they prepared roughly three times more food than could be consumed, with the excess carelessly thrown into the flames.

He reflects on their improvident, hand-to-mouth lifestyle and sleeping on watch, concluding that despite their boldness for brief engagements, they are entirely unsuited for any prolonged or organized campaign.
Jim is particularly surprised that Silver, typically astute and disciplined, offers no criticism of their recklessness, even as he eats with Captain Flint, his parrot, perched on his shoulder.

events.text_segment:
Just then a man hailed us from the fire that breakfast was ready, and we were soon seated here and there about the sand over biscuit and fried junk. They had lit a fire fit to roast an ox, and it was now grown so hot that they could only approach it from the windward, and even there not without precaution. In the same wasteful spirit, they had cooked, I suppose, three times more than we could eat; and one of them, with an empty laugh, threw what was left into the fire, which blazed and roared again over this unusual fuel. I never in my life saw men so careless of the morrow; hand to mouth is the only word that can describe their way of doing; and what with wasted food and sleeping sentries, though they were bold enough for a brush and be done with it, I could see their entire unfitness for anything like a prolonged campaign.
Even Silver, eating away, with Captain Flint upon his shoulder, had not a word of blame for their recklessness. And this the more surprised me, for I thought he had never shown himself so cunning as he did then.

It was clear that he was turning something over in his mind. The morning passed slowly, each of us alert for the slightest sound from the woods beyond our little fort.

detailed_summary: Silver addresses his men, boasting that they are fortunate to have his intelligence guiding them and claiming he has achieved his objectives.

Silver asserts that once the treasure is secured, the group that controls the boats will ultimately have the upper hand.
He continues by discussing Jim, stating that Jim's last interaction with his allies provided useful intelligence, but that phase is now concluded.
Silver declares his intention to keep Jim tethered during the treasure hunt, treating him as a valuable asset or 'gold' in case of 'accidents'.

He then promises the men that once they have secured both the ship and the treasure and are sailing away, they will negotiate with Jim and give him a share for his perceived 'kindness', thereby restoring the pirates' hope and confidence, and likely his own.

events.title: Jim's Deepening Despair and Multifaceted Anxiety
detailed_summary: While Silver's speech lifts the pirates' spirits, Jim feels profoundly dejected.

He recognizes that if Silver's outlined scheme proves successful, the already duplicitous pirate would not hesitate to betray the doctor's party again, preferring wealth and freedom with the pirates over the mere escape from hanging offered by his agreement with Dr. Livesey.

Jim considers the grave danger he would face even if Silver were forced to remain loyal to Dr. Livesey, envisioning a desperate struggle for survival—a crippled man and a boy against five able seamen—should the pirates' suspicions about Silver's allegiance turn to certainty.

His distress is amplified by the unresolved mysteries surrounding his friends' actions: their desertion of the stockade, the surrender of the treasure chart, and Dr. Livesey's cryptic warning to Silver about expecting trouble upon finding the treasure.
These combined anxieties leave Jim with no appetite and a heavy heart as he embarks on the treasure hunt with his captors.

It was no wonder the men were in a good humour now. For my part, I was horribly cast down. Should the scheme he had now sketched prove feasible, Silver, already doubly a traitor, would not hesitate to adopt it. He had still a foot in either camp, and there was no doubt he would prefer wealth and freedom with the pirates to a bare escape from hanging, which was the best he had to hope on our side.
Nay, and even if things so fell out that he was forced to keep his faith with Dr. Livesey, even then what danger lay before us! What a moment that would be when the suspicions of his followers turned to certainty and he and I should have to fight for dear life—he a cripple and I a boy—against five strong and active seamen!
Add to this double apprehension the mystery that still hung over the behaviour of my friends, their unexplained desertion of the stockade, their inexplicable cession of the chart, or harder still to understand, the doctor’s last warning to Silver, “Look out for squalls when you find it,” and you will readily believe how little taste I found in my breakfast and with how uneasy a heart I set forth behind my captors on the quest for treasure.

events.title: The Treasure Hunting Expedition Sets Out
detailed_summary: The treasure-seeking party presents an odd appearance, dressed in dirty sailor attire and, with the exception of Jim, heavily armed.
Silver is particularly well-equipped with two slung guns, a cutlass, and pistols in his coat pockets, while his parrot, Captain Flint, sits on his shoulder chattering.
Jim is led by a rope tied around his waist, the end held by Silver, making Jim feel like a 'dancing bear'.
Other pirates are laden with tools such as picks and shovels, which were their first priority brought ashore, and provisions like pork, bread, and brandy.

Jim observes that all their supplies originate from the loyal party's stock, confirming Silver's earlier statement about striking a bargain with the doctor; without it, the mutineers would have faced severe shortages.
The entire group, including a man with a head injury who should have been resting, proceeds to the beach where two gigs, showing signs of the pirates' previous drunken neglect, await them.
For safety, both boats are used, and the party divides itself between them to set off across the anchorage.

events.text_segment:
We made a curious figure, had anyone been there to see us—all in soiled sailor clothes and all but me armed to the teeth. Silver had two guns slung about him—one before and one behind—besides the great cutlass at his waist and a pistol in each pocket of his square-tailed coat. To complete his strange appearance, Captain Flint sat perched upon his shoulder and gabbling odds and ends of purposeless sea-talk. I had a line about my waist and followed obediently after the sea-cook, who held the loose end of the rope, now in his free hand, now between his powerful teeth. For all the world, I was led like a dancing bear.
The other men were variously burthened, some carrying picks and shovels—for that had been the very first necessary they brought ashore from the Hispaniola—others laden with pork, bread, and brandy for the midday meal. All the stores, I observed, came from our stock, and I could see the truth of Silver’s words the night before. Had he not struck a bargain with the doctor, he and his mutineers, deserted by the ship, must have been driven to subsist on clear water and the proceeds of their hunting. Water would have been little to their taste; a sailor is not usually a good shot; and besides all that, when they were so short of eatables, it was not likely they would be very flush of powder.
Well, thus equipped, we all set out—even the fellow with the broken head, who should certainly have kept in shadow—and straggled, one after another, to the beach, where the two gigs awaited us. Even these bore trace of the drunken folly of the pirates, one in a broken thwart, and both in their muddy and unbailed condition. Both were to be carried along with us for the sake of safety; and so, with our numbers divided between them, we set forth upon the bosom of the anchorage.

events.title: Navigating by Chart and Ascending to the Plateau
detailed_summary: While rowing across the anchorage, the pirates discuss the treasure map, recognizing that the large red cross marking the treasure's location is too imprecise to be a definitive guide.
The chart's instructions refer to specific landmarks: 'Tall tree, Spy-glass shoulder, bearing a point to the N. of N.N.E. Skeleton Island E.S.E. and by E. Ten feet.'
The main landmark is a 'tall tree,' but the nearby plateau is densely covered with pine trees of various heights, making identification from their current position challenging.
Despite the ambiguity, most pirates aboard the boats eagerly select their own candidate for the 'tall tree,' though Long John Silver advises them to wait until they are on site.
Following Silver's direction to row slowly to conserve energy, they eventually land at the mouth of the island's second river, which flows down from the Spy-glass hill.
Turning left, they begin to climb the slope towards the plateau, initially facing difficult terrain with heavy, miry ground and dense, marsh-like vegetation.

As they progress, the ground becomes steeper and stonier, and the forest more open, leading them into a more pleasant area of the island characterized by fragrant broom, flowering shrubs, green nutmeg trees, and tall pines.
The fresh, stirring air under the bright sunlight provides a welcome sensory refreshment.

events.text_segment:
As we pulled over, there was some discussion on the chart. The red cross was, of course, far too large to be a guide; and the terms of the note on the back, as you will hear, admitted of some ambiguity. They ran, the reader may remember, thus: Tall tree, Spy-glass shoulder, bearing a point to the N. of N.N.E. Skeleton Island E.S.E. and by E. Ten feet.
A tall tree was thus the principal mark. Now, right before us the anchorage was bounded by a plateau from two to three hundred feet high, adjoining on the north the sloping southern shoulder of the Spy-glass and rising again towards the south into the rough, cliffy eminence called the Mizzenmast Hill. The top of the plateau was dotted thickly with pine-trees of varying height. Every here and there, one of a different species rose forty or fifty feet clear above its neighbours, and which of these was the particular “tall tree” of Captain Flint could only be decided on the spot, and by the readings of the compass.
Yet, although that was the case, every man on board the boats had picked a favourite of his own ere we were half-way over, Long John alone shrugging his shoulders and bidding them wait till they were there.
We pulled easily, by Silver’s directions, not to weary the hands prematurely, and after quite a long passage, landed at the mouth of the second river—that which runs down a woody cleft of the Spy-glass. Thence, bending to our left, we began to ascend the slope towards the plateau.
At the first outset, heavy, miry ground and a matted, marish vegetation greatly delayed our progress; but by little and little the hill began to steepen and become stony under foot, and the wood to change its character and to grow in a more open order. It was, indeed, a most pleasant portion of the island that we were now approaching. A heavy-scented broom and many flowering shrubs had almost taken the place of grass. Thickets of green nutmeg-trees were dotted here and there with the red columns and the broad shadow of the pines; and the first mingled their spice with the aroma of the others. The air, besides, was fresh and stirring, and this, under the sheer sunbeams, was a wonderful refreshment to our senses.

Presently, we came out upon a pleasant open space, fragrant with broom and other flowering shrubs, green nutmeg trees, and tall pines, the air fresh and stirring under the bright sun, and all our spirits rose with the change.

events.title: Ominous Discovery of an Artificially Placed Skeleton
detailed_summary: The pirates fan out across the terrain, moving boisterously, shouting and leaping as they advance.
Silver and Jim, with Jim still tethered, follow more slowly in the center, some distance behind the main group; Jim occasionally has to assist Silver to prevent him from falling on the loose gravel.
After covering about half a mile and nearing the top of the plateau, a pirate on the far left flank suddenly begins to shout repeatedly, as if in terror.
The other pirates, including Morgan who quickly dismisses the idea that the treasure itself has been found, rush towards the source of the cries.
Upon reaching the spot, they discover a human skeleton at the foot of a large pine tree, entangled in a green creeper which has even dislodged some of the smaller bones.
Jim observes that this sight sends a momentary chill through everyone present.
George Merry, venturing closer to examine the tattered clothing, identifies the remains as those of a seaman by the quality of the cloth.
Silver concurs, dryly noting one wouldn't expect to find a bishop there, but immediately questions the unnatural way the bones are arranged.

A more careful examination reveals that, despite some disturbance likely from scavengers or plant growth, the skeleton lies perfectly straight, with its feet pointing one way and its hands extended above its head, pointing in the exact opposite direction, like a diver.

events.text_segment:
The party spread itself abroad, in a fan shape, shouting and leaping to and fro. About the centre, and a good way behind the rest, Silver and I followed—I tethered by my rope, he ploughing, with deep pants, among the sliding gravel. From time to time, indeed, I had to lend him a hand, or he must have missed his footing and fallen backward down the hill.
We had thus proceeded for about half a mile and were approaching the brow of the plateau when the man upon the farthest left began to cry aloud, as if in terror. Shout after shout came from him, and the others began to run in his direction.
“He can’t ’a found the treasure,” said old Morgan, hurrying past us from the right, “for that’s clean a-top.”
Indeed, as we found when we also reached the spot, it was something very different. At the foot of a pretty big pine and involved in a green creeper, which had even partly lifted some of the smaller bones, a human skeleton lay, with a few shreds of clothing, on the ground. I believe a chill struck for a moment to every heart.
“He was a seaman,” said George Merry, who, bolder than the rest, had gone up close and was examining the rags of clothing. “Leastways, this is good sea-cloth.”
“Aye, aye,” said Silver; “like enough; you wouldn’t look to find a bishop here, I reckon. But what sort of a way is that for bones to lie? ’Tain’t in natur’.”
Indeed, on a second glance, it seemed impossible to fancy that the body was in a natural position. But for some disarray (the work, perhaps, of the birds that had fed upon him or of the slow-growing creeper that had gradually enveloped his remains) the man lay perfectly straight—his feet pointing in one direction, his hands, raised above his head like a diver’s, pointing directly in the opposite.

Drunk with the prospect of gold, they crashed through the undergrowth, heedless of the brambles that tore at their clothes and the branches that whipped their faces. Silver, with his crutch, hobbled along at the rear, his eyes darting from side to side, ever watchful for danger or opportunity. The sun beat down mercilessly, and the air was thick with the scent of pine and the distant tang of the sea.

Jim, keeping to the edge of the group, felt his heart pounding in his chest. He clutched his pistol tightly, uncertain whether he feared the pirates more than the unknown terrors of the island. As they pressed on, the ground began to rise, and the trees grew sparser. Suddenly, one of the men gave a cry and pointed ahead. There, on the crest of a small hill, stood a solitary figure, gaunt and wild-eyed, his clothes in tatters and his hair and beard matted with dirt. It was Ben Gunn, the marooned sailor, who had watched their approach with a mixture of hope and fear.

Silver raised his hand for silence, and the party halted. For a moment, no one spoke. Then Ben Gunn called out in a hoarse voice, "Who be ye, friends or foes?"

Silver answered him with a smile, his voice oily and persuasive. "Friends, matey, friends! We've come for the treasure, same as you."

Ben Gunn hesitated, then beckoned them forward. The party surged ahead, their greed momentarily overcoming their caution, as the promise of Flint's treasure drew them onward into the heart of the island.

events.title: Deciphering Flint's Macabre Signpost and Rising Dread
detailed_summary: Silver announces he has an idea and directs the men to take a compass bearing along the line of the skeleton, using the prominent peak of Skeleton Island as a reference point.
The measurement confirms that the skeleton is aligned directly towards Skeleton Island, with the compass reading E.S.E. and by E., matching a clue from the treasure map.
Silver triumphantly identifies the skeleton as a 'p'inter' deliberately arranged by the deceased Captain Flint, calling it one of his characteristic macabre jokes.

He recounts that Flint was on the island alone with six crewmen, all of whom he killed; this skeleton, Silver surmises, is Allardyce (a man Morgan remembers owing him money and taking his knife), positioned by compass as a guide.

The pirates become uneasy, noting the absence of any personal effects like a knife or money with the skeleton, which they find unnatural, as Flint wasn't known for robbing the dead and birds wouldn't take such items.

Silver agrees the scene is neither natural nor pleasant, ominously remarking that if Flint were alive, their current group of six would be in grave danger, just like Flint's original six companions who are now bones.
While Morgan confirms Flint's death, another pirate voices fear of Flint's lingering spirit, recalling his violent and terrifying end.
Another pirate adds to the chilling atmosphere by describing Flint's last moments: raging, demanding rum, and singing 'Fifteen Men,' a song that has haunted him ever since.
Silver attempts to curtail the superstitious talk, insisting Flint is dead and won't walk by day, urging them to focus on finding the doubloons.

Despite Silver's efforts and the bright daylight, the pirates are deeply unnerved, abandoning their earlier boisterousness to move closely together and speak in hushed tones, their spirits overshadowed by the terror of the dead buccaneer.

“I’ve taken a notion into my old numbskull,” observed Silver. “Here’s the compass; there’s the tip-top p’int o’ Skeleton Island, stickin’ out like a tooth. Just take a bearing, will you, along the line of them bones.”
It was done. The body pointed straight in the direction of the island, and the compass read duly E.S.E. and by E.
“I thought so,” cried the cook; “this here is a p’inter. Right up there is our line for the Pole Star and the jolly dollars. But, by thunder! If it don’t make me cold inside to think of Flint. This is one of his jokes, and no mistake. Him and these six was alone here; he killed ’em, every man; and this one he hauled here and laid down by compass, shiver my timbers! They’re long bones, and the hair’s been yellow. Aye, that would be Allardyce. You mind Allardyce, Tom Morgan?”
“Aye, aye,” returned Morgan; “I mind him; he owed me money, he did, and took my knife ashore with him.”
“Speaking of knives,” said another, “why don’t we find his’n lying round? Flint warn’t the man to pick a seaman’s pocket; and the birds, I guess, would leave it be.”
“By the powers, and that’s true!” cried Silver.
“There ain’t a thing left here,” said Merry, still feeling round among the bones; “not a copper doit nor a baccy box. It don’t look nat’ral to me.”
“No, by gum, it don’t,” agreed Silver; “not nat’ral, nor not nice, says you. Great guns! Messmates, but if Flint was living, this would be a hot spot for you and me. Six they were, and six are we; and bones is what they are now.”
“I saw him dead with these here deadlights,” said Morgan. “Billy took me in. There he laid, with penny-pieces on his eyes.”
“Dead—aye, sure enough he’s dead and gone below,” said the fellow with the bandage; “but if ever sperrit walked, it would be Flint’s. Dear heart, but he died bad, did Flint!”
“Aye, that he did,” observed another; “now he raged, and now he hollered for the rum, and now he sang. ‘Fifteen Men’ were his only song, mates; and I tell you true, I never rightly liked to hear it since. It was main hot, and the windy was open, and I hear that old song comin’ out as clear as clear—and the death-haul on the man already.”
“Come, come,” said Silver; “stow this talk. He’s dead, and he don’t walk, that I know; leastways, he won’t walk by day, and you may lay to that. Care killed a cat. Fetch ahead for the doubloons.”
We started, certainly; but in spite of the hot sun and the staring daylight, the pirates no longer ran separate and shouting through the wood, but kept side by side and spoke with bated breath. The terror of the dead buccaneer had fallen on their spirits.

He took a bearing by the compass, with the skeleton as a pointer, and the line ran up the hill towards the old stockade, the direction of the tall peak on Skeleton Island.

“Come, that’s Flint’s doing, that is,” cried Silver. “He always had a fancy for the macabre, had old Flint. This here skeleton’s a pointer, that’s what it is. It’s one of his jokes, and no mistake. And where’s his money? Not natural, I say. Flint weren’t the man to rob the dead, and birds couldn’t carry off a knife nor money.”

“It ain’t natural, nor it ain’t nice,” agreed Silver. “Suppose Flint was alive and here now, what would six of us be? Just the same as them—bones.”

“Flint’s dead, long ago,” said Morgan.

“Ay, sure enough he is, and he won’t walk by day, neither. But there’s some that’s feared of the dead—ay, and some that’s feared of Flint’s ghost, too,” said another pirate, shuddering.

“I mind his last moments,” said another. “He were raging, for rum, and singing ‘Fifteen Men’—that song’s haunted me ever since.”

“Avast there!” cried Silver, sharply. “This ain’t no time for fear or ghost stories. Flint’s dead, and he won’t walk by day. Let’s get to the doubloons, mates.”

But for all Silver’s bravado, the men were cowed. The bright sun shone overhead, but the six pirates huddled close, their voices low, their spirits chilled by the terror of the dead buccaneer.

“I’ve taken a notion into my old numbskull,” observed Silver, “and I’ll tell you what it is. We’re all in a bit of a fix, mates, and there’s no denying it. The ship’s gone, the doctor and squire are against us, and the treasure—well, we don’t know where it is, do we? But I’ve been thinking, and I say we keep our heads cool and our powder dry. There’s more ways than one to skin a cat, as the saying goes.”

The men around him shifted uneasily, their faces drawn and anxious in the flickering light of the campfire. The night air was thick with the scent of salt and pine, and somewhere in the darkness, a night bird called. Silver’s single leg thumped the ground as he leaned forward, his good eye glinting with cunning.

“Now, mates,” he continued, “we’ve come too far to turn back empty-handed. The doctor and his lot—they’re clever, I’ll grant you that. But they’re not pirates, not like us. They don’t know the tricks of the trade. We’ve got the map, and that’s worth more than all the gold in the world, if you know how to use it.”

Dick, the youngest of the crew, looked up nervously. “But what if they come for us, Silver? What if they’ve got guns?”

Silver grinned, showing his yellow teeth. “Let ‘em come, lad. We’ll be ready for ‘em. And as for guns, we’ve got a few tricks up our sleeves yet. The main thing is to keep our wits about us. No panicking, no running off half-cocked. We stick together, and we’ll see this through.”

Morgan, another of the crew, spat into the fire. “Aye, but what about the boy? Hawkins, he’s a slippery one. He’s the one as got us into this mess.”

Silver’s face darkened for a moment, but then he shrugged. “The boy’s got spirit, I’ll give him that. But he’s just a lad. We’ll keep an eye on him, don’t you worry. He won’t be slipping away again, not if I have anything to say about it.”

The men murmured their agreement, though unease still lingered in the air. Silver’s confidence was infectious, but the dangers they faced were real enough. The island was a place of secrets and shadows, and every man there knew that fortune could turn in an instant.

Silver poked at the fire with his crutch, sending a shower of sparks into the night. “So here’s my notion, mates. We bide our time. We watch and wait. The doctor and his friends—they’ll have to come to us sooner or later. And when they do, we’ll be ready. The treasure’s out there, and by thunder, we’ll have it yet!”

A cheer went up from the men, their spirits lifted by Silver’s words. For a moment, hope flickered in their hearts, and the promise of gold shone bright in their eyes. But in the darkness beyond the firelight, the island watched and waited, silent and mysterious as ever.

events.title: Rest on the Ascent and Ominous Recollections of Flint
detailed_summary: The group paused on the plateau after their climb to allow Long John Silver and the unwell members to rest.
Their vantage point offered a wide view of the Cape of the Woods, the anchorage, Skeleton Island, and the eastern sea.
The Spy-glass mountain loomed above, enhancing the sense of isolation, broken only by distant waves and insect sounds.
Silver used his compass for bearings, confidently stating the treasure's location was now simple to determine and suggested they eat first.
Morgan admitted he had no appetite, attributing his unease to thoughts of the deceased Captain Flint.
Silver remarked that Morgan should consider himself fortunate that Flint was dead.
Another pirate, with a shudder, described Flint as an 'ugly devil,' specifically mentioning his blue face.
Merry added that Flint's blue complexion was a consequence of his excessive rum consumption, confirming it as factual.

events.text_segment:
Partly from the damping influence of this alarm, partly to rest Silver and the sick folk, the whole party sat down as soon as they had gained the brow of the ascent.
The plateau being somewhat tilted towards the west, this spot on which we had paused commanded a wide prospect on either hand. Before us, over the tree-tops, we beheld the Cape of the Woods fringed with surf; behind, we not only looked down upon the anchorage and Skeleton Island, but saw—clear across the spit and the eastern lowlands—a great field of open sea upon the east. Sheer above us rose the Spy-glass, here dotted with single pines, there black with precipices. There was no sound but that of the distant breakers, mounting from all round, and the chirp of countless insects in the brush. Not a man, not a sail, upon the sea; the very largeness of the view increased the sense of solitude.
Silver, as he sat, took certain bearings with his compass.
“There are three ‘tall trees,’” said he, “about in the right line from Skeleton Island. ‘Spy-glass shoulder,’ I take it, means that lower p’int there. It’s child’s play to find the stuff now. I’ve half a mind to dine first.”
“I don’t feel sharp,” growled Morgan. “Thinkin’ o’ Flint—I think it were—as done me.”
“Ah, well, my son, you praise your stars he’s dead,” said Silver.
“He were an ugly devil,” cried a third pirate with a shudder; “that blue in the face too!”
“That was how the rum took him,” added Merry. “Blue! Well, I reckon he was blue. That’s a true word.”

events.title: The Phantom Singer and Abject Terror Among Pirates
detailed_summary: Following their discovery of the skeleton and subsequent morbid thoughts, the pirates' voices had dropped to near whispers.
Suddenly, from the midst of the trees, a thin, high, trembling voice began to sing the familiar words of 'Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!'
Jim Hawkins had never witnessed men so dreadfully affected; the color drained from the pirates' faces as if by magic.
Some pirates leaped to their feet, others clung to one another, and Morgan collapsed onto the ground in terror.
Merry cried out, attributing the voice to Flint.
The song stopped as abruptly as it had begun, as though a hand had been placed over the singer's mouth.
To Jim Hawkins, the song had sounded pleasant and light amidst the sunny greenery, making the pirates' extreme reaction all the more baffling.

events.text_segment:
Ever since they had found the skeleton and got upon this train of thought, they had spoken lower and lower, and they had almost got to whispering by now, so that the sound of their talk hardly interrupted the silence of the wood. All of a sudden, out of the middle of the trees in front of us, a thin, high, trembling voice struck up the well-known air and words: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
I never have seen men more dreadfully affected than the pirates. The colour went from their six faces like enchantment; some leaped to their feet, some clawed hold of others; Morgan grovelled on the ground.
“It’s Flint, by ——!” cried Merry.
The song had stopped as suddenly as it began—broken off, you would have said, in the middle of a note, as though someone had laid his hand upon the singer’s mouth. Coming through the clear, sunny atmosphere among the green tree-tops, I thought it had sounded airily and sweetly; and the effect on my companions was the stranger.

events.title: Silver's Attempted Reassurance and the Voice's Eerie Return
detailed_summary: Silver, though visibly pale, struggled to speak and tried to dismiss the event, urging the men to prepare to move on.
He suggested the voice belonged to a living person playing a prank, not a ghost.
As Silver spoke, his courage began to return, and some color came back to his face, which started to reassure the others.
Just as the men were regaining composure, the same voice was heard again, not singing, but as a faint, distant wail echoing from the Spy-glass.
The voice cried out “Darby M’Graw!” repeatedly, then, in a slightly higher tone and with an omitted oath, demanded, “Fetch aft the rum, Darby!”
The buccaneers remained frozen to the spot, their eyes wide with terror, staring silently even after the voice had faded.

events.text_segment:
“Come,” said Silver, struggling with his ashen lips to get the word out; “this won’t do. Stand by to go about. This is a rum start, and I can’t name the voice, but it’s someone skylarking—someone that’s flesh and blood, and you may lay to that.”
His courage had come back as he spoke, and some of the colour to his face along with it. Already the others had begun to lend an ear to this encouragement and were coming a little to themselves, when the same voice broke out again—not this time singing, but in a faint distant hail that echoed yet fainter among the clefts of the Spy-glass.
“Darby M’Graw,” it wailed—for that is the word that best describes the sound—“Darby M’Graw! Darby M’Graw!” again and again and again; and then rising a little higher, and with an oath that I leave out: “Fetch aft the rum, Darby!”
The buccaneers remained rooted to the ground, their eyes starting from their heads. Long after the voice had died away they still stared in silence, dreadfully, before them.
“That fixes it!” gasped one. “Let’s go.”
“They was his last words,” moaned Morgan, “his last words above board.”
Dick had his Bible out and was praying volubly. He had been well brought up, had Dick, before he came to sea and fell among bad companions.

detailed_summary: Despite the pervasive fear, Long John Silver remained determined, his teeth audibly rattling but his resolve intact.

The rest of the pirates were too frightened to speak, huddling close to Silver as if his daring offered them some measure of protection, while Silver himself had largely overcome his own fear.
Silver then questioned the nature of the phenomenon, pointing out that the voice produced an echo, something he argued a spirit would not naturally possess.

Still Silver was unconquered. I could hear his teeth rattle in his head, but he had not yet surrendered.
“Nobody in this here island ever heard of Darby,” he muttered; “not one but us that’s here.” And then, making a great effort: “Shipmates,” he cried, “I’m here to get that stuff, and I’ll not be beat by man or devil. events.title: Identifying the Voice as Ben Gunn's: Relief and Renewed Pursuit
detailed_summary: Although Jim Hawkins found Silver's reasoning about the echo unconvincing, it significantly reassured the superstitious George Merry.
Merry commended Silver's intelligence and urged the crew to reconsider their fear, stating he believed they were mistaken in their terror.
He then observed that while the voice resembled Flint's, it wasn't identical and sounded more like someone else's.
Silver suddenly and loudly identified the voice as belonging to Ben Gunn.
Morgan, jumping to his knees, enthusiastically agreed with Silver's assessment.
Dick questioned if it mattered whose voice it was, since Ben Gunn was not physically present any more than Flint.
The older pirates dismissed Dick's comment with disdain, Merry asserting that Ben Gunn was of no consequence, whether alive or dead.
The pirates' spirits remarkably lifted, their natural complexions returned, and they soon resumed chatting, pausing intermittently to listen.

After hearing no further sounds, they picked up their tools and continued their quest, with Merry leading, using Silver's compass to stay on course from Skeleton Island, proving that Ben Gunn, alive or dead, was not feared.

events.text_segment:
This argument seemed weak enough to me. But you can never tell what will affect the superstitious, and to my wonder, George Merry was greatly relieved.
“Well, that’s so,” he said. “You’ve a head upon your shoulders, John, and no mistake. ’Bout ship, mates! This here crew is on a wrong tack, I do believe. And come to think on it, it was like Flint’s voice, I grant you, but not just so clear-away like it, after all. It was liker somebody else’s voice now—it was liker—”
“By the powers, Ben Gunn!” roared Silver.
“Aye, and so it were,” cried Morgan, springing on his knees. “Ben Gunn it were!”
“It don’t make much odds, do it, now?” asked Dick. “Ben Gunn’s not here in the body any more’n Flint.”
But the older hands greeted this remark with scorn.
“Why, nobody minds Ben Gunn,” cried Merry; “dead or alive, nobody minds him.”
It was extraordinary how their spirits had returned and how the natural colour had revived in their faces. Soon they were chatting together, with intervals of listening; and not long after, hearing no further sound, they shouldered the tools and set forth again, Merry walking first with Silver’s compass to keep them on the right line with Skeleton Island. He had said the truth: dead or alive, nobody minded Ben Gunn.

events.title: The March Resumes: Dick's Worsening Condition and the Search for the Trees
detailed_summary: Only Dick continued to show fear, clutching his Bible and looking around nervously, but he found no support from the others; Silver even teased him about his caution.
Silver told Dick he had ruined his Bible and questioned its worth against a spirit, snapping his fingers dismissively.
Dick remained unconsoled, and Jim Hawkins noticed the young man was clearly becoming ill, his fever—predicted by Dr. Livesey—escalating due to the heat, fatigue, and shock.
The group moved through open terrain on the plateau, which sloped slightly to the west.
Pines of various sizes grew sparsely, and wide, sun-baked clearings lay between clusters of nutmeg and azalea.
Traveling roughly northwest, they moved nearer to the Spy-glass's base on one side, while on the other, their view expanded over the western bay where Jim had previously been adrift in the coracle.
They reached the first of the designated tall trees, but upon checking bearings, it proved to be the incorrect one.
The second tall tree they located also turned out to be the wrong marker.

Dick alone still held his Bible, and looked around him as he went, with fearful glances; but he found no sympathy, and Silver even joked him on his precautions.
“I told you,” said he—“I told you you had sp’iled your Bible. If it ain’t no good to swear by, what do you suppose a sperrit would give for it? Not that!” and he snapped his big fingers, halting a moment on his crutch.
But Dick was not to be comforted; indeed, it was soon plain to me that the lad was falling sick; hastened by heat, exhaustion, and the shock of his alarm, the fever, predicted by Dr. Livesey, was evidently growing swiftly higher.
It was fine open walking here, upon the summit; our way lay a little downhill, for, as I have said, the plateau tilted towards the west. The pines, great and small, grew wide apart; and even between the clumps of nutmeg and azalea, wide open spaces baked in the hot sunshine. Striking, as we did, pretty near north-west across the island, we drew, on the one hand, ever nearer under the shoulders of the Spy-glass, and on the other, looked ever wider over that western bay where I had once tossed and trembled in the coracle.
The first of the tall trees was reached, and by the bearings proved the wrong one. So with the second.

events.title: The True Landmark Tree and the Overwhelming Grip of Gold Fever
detailed_summary: The third tree they found was a colossal specimen, soaring almost two hundred feet high with a massive red trunk and a broad shadow, making it a prominent landmark visible from both east and west coasts.
However, it was not the tree's size that captivated the pirates, but the knowledge that seven hundred thousand pounds in gold was supposedly buried beneath its shadow.
As they drew closer to this tree, the intense desire for the money completely eclipsed their earlier fears.
Their eyes began to burn with anticipation, their steps became quicker and lighter, and their entire focus was consumed by the immense fortune awaiting them.
Silver, hobbling on his crutch, grunted with effort, his nostrils flared, and he cursed like a madman when flies landed on his heated face.
He violently tugged the rope securing Jim Hawkins to him and frequently cast deadly glares at the boy.

Jim clearly perceived that Silver made no effort to conceal his intentions: in the immediate proximity of the gold, all promises and warnings were forgotten, and Silver fully intended to seize the treasure, retake the Hispaniola by night, eliminate every honest person on the island, and sail away laden with riches and crimes as originally planned.

events.text_segment:
The third rose nearly two hundred feet into the air above a clump of underwood—a giant of a vegetable, with a red column as big as a cottage, and a wide shadow around in which a company could have manoeuvred. It was conspicuous far to sea both on the east and west and might have been entered as a sailing mark upon the chart.
But it was not its size that now impressed my companions; it was the knowledge that seven hundred thousand pounds in gold lay somewhere buried below its spreading shadow. The thought of the money, as they drew nearer, swallowed up their previous terrors. Their eyes burned in their heads; their feet grew speedier and lighter; their whole soul was bound up in that fortune, that whole lifetime of extravagance and pleasure, that lay waiting there for each of them.
Silver hobbled, grunting, on his crutch; his nostrils stood out and quivered; he cursed like a madman when the flies settled on his hot and shiny countenance; he plucked furiously at the line that held me to him and from time to time turned his eyes upon me with a deadly look. Certainly he took no pains to hide his thoughts, and certainly I read them like print.

events.title: Narrator's Dread and Haunting Memories on the Plateau's Edge
detailed_summary: Disturbed by Silver's threatening behavior and the evident danger, Jim Hawkins struggled to maintain the swift pace set by the gold-crazed pirates.
Whenever Jim stumbled, Silver would harshly pull the rope and glare at him with murderous intent.

Jim imagined that the now-peaceful grove must have once echoed with their dying cries, and the thought made him feel as if he could still hear them.
The group finally arrived at the edge of the dense vegetation near the treasure site.

events.text_segment:
Shaken as I was with these alarms, it was hard for me to keep up with the rapid pace of the treasure-hunters. Now and again I stumbled, and it was then that Silver plucked so roughly at the rope and launched at me his murderous glances. Dick, who had dropped behind us and now brought up the rear, was babbling to himself both prayers and curses as his fever kept rising. This also added to my wretchedness, and to crown all, I was haunted by the thought of the tragedy that had once been acted on that plateau, when that ungodly buccaneer with the blue face—he who died at Savannah, singing and shouting for drink—had there, with his own hand, cut down his six accomplices. events.title: The Shocking Discovery: An Empty Cache, The Treasure Gone
detailed_summary: Merry shouted enthusiastically, and the pirates at the front of the group began to run towards the expected location of the treasure.
Suddenly, less than ten yards further, they were seen to stop abruptly, and a low cry of dismay arose from them.
Silver increased his pace, digging his crutch into the ground with manic energy, and in the next moment, he and Jim Hawkins also came to a standstill.
Before them was a large excavation, evidently not of recent origin, as its sides had caved in and grass had begun to grow at the bottom.
Inside the pit lay the broken shaft of a pickaxe and several scattered boards from packing-cases.
On one of these boards, Jim Hawkins noticed the name 'Walrus'—the name of Captain Flint's ship—branded with a hot iron.
The situation was unequivocally clear: the treasure cache had been previously discovered and looted; the seven hundred thousand pounds were no longer there.

events.title: The Empty Pit and Silver's Shifting Allegiance
detailed_summary: The six men are profoundly shocked to discover the treasure pit is empty.
Long John Silver, unlike the others, recovers swiftly from the disappointment, immediately adapting his strategy.
He covertly hands Jim a double-barrelled pistol and cautions him to prepare for trouble.
Silver strategically moves himself and Jim slightly apart from the other five buccaneers, using the hollow for separation.
He communicates their dangerous predicament to Jim with a meaningful nod.
Jim, repulsed by Silver's repeated betrayals, quietly remarks on Silver having switched allegiances once more.
The enraged buccaneers jump into the pit, digging frantically with their fingers and tossing aside planks, only to find a single two-guinea coin.
Merry angrily confronts Silver, deriding his supposed grand treasure and labeling him an incompetent leader.
Silver responds with cool insolence, suggesting they might discover some pig-nuts.
Merry, further infuriated, accuses Silver of having known all along that the treasure was gone.
Silver mockingly comments on Merry's renewed ambition to be captain.
This time, all the buccaneers align with Merry, climbing out of the excavation and casting furious looks at Silver.
Notably, the five opposing buccaneers position themselves on the side of the pit opposite to Silver and Jim.

events.text_segment:
There never was such an overturn in this world. Each of these six men was as though he had been struck. But with Silver the blow passed almost instantly. Every thought of his soul had been set full-stretch, like a racer, on that money; well, he was brought up, in a single second, dead; and he kept his head, found his temper, and changed his plan before the others had had time to realize the disappointment.
“Jim,” he whispered, “take that, and stand by for trouble.”
And he passed me a double-barrelled pistol.
At the same time, he began quietly moving northward, and in a few steps had put the hollow between us two and the other five. Then he looked at me and nodded, as much as to say, “Here is a narrow corner,” as, indeed, I thought it was. His looks were not quite friendly, and I was so revolted at these constant changes that I could not forbear whispering, “So you’ve changed sides again.”
There was no time left for him to answer in. The buccaneers, with oaths and cries, began to leap, one after another, into the pit and to dig with their fingers, throwing the boards aside as they did so. Morgan found a piece of gold. He held it up with a perfect spout of oaths. It was a two-guinea piece, and it went from hand to hand among them for a quarter of a minute.
“Two guineas!” roared Merry, shaking it at Silver. “That’s your seven hundred thousand pounds, is it? You’re the man for bargains, ain’t you? You’re him that never bungled nothing, you wooden-headed lubber!”
“Dig away, boys,” said Silver with the coolest insolence; “you’ll find some pig-nuts and I shouldn’t wonder.”
“Pig-nuts!” repeated Merry, in a scream. “Mates, do you hear that? I tell you now, that man there knew it all along. Look in the face of him and you’ll see it wrote there.”
“Ah, Merry,” remarked Silver, “standing for cap’n again? You’re a pushing lad, to be sure.”
But this time everyone was entirely in Merry’s favour. They began to scramble out of the excavation, darting furious glances behind them. One thing I observed, which looked well for us: they all got out upon the opposite side from Silver.

He moved with surprising agility, striking out at any who came within reach, his voice rising above the din as he barked orders to his men. The pirates, emboldened by their leader's example, fought with a ferocity born of desperation, their eyes wild and their teeth bared in grimaces of rage.

Dr. Livesey, his spectacles askew and his coat torn, fought with a cool precision that belied the chaos around him. But we were alive, and for the moment, at least, we had held our ground against the onslaught. As I looked around at my companions, battered but unbowed, I felt a surge of hope. Perhaps, after all, we might yet prevail against the odds.

events.title: Confrontation and Sudden Ambush
detailed_summary: A tense standoff occurs, with Silver and Jim on one side of the pit and the five hostile buccaneers on the other, no one initiating an attack.
Silver maintains his composure, standing upright on his crutch and observing his adversaries coolly.
Merry attempts to rally the other pirates for an assault, blaming Silver for their predicament and singling out Jim as a target.
Just as Merry raises his arm and voice to lead the charge, three musket shots erupt from the nearby dense bushes.
Merry collapses headfirst into the excavation pit.
The buccaneer with the bandage spins around and falls dead, his body still twitching.
The remaining three pirates turn and flee in panic.
Without hesitation, Long John Silver fires both barrels of his pistol into the struggling Merry.
As Merry succumbs to his injuries, Silver grimly states that he has 'settled' him.
Immediately following this, Doctor Livesey, Gray, and Ben Gunn emerge from the nutmeg-trees, their muskets smoking.

events.text_segment:
Well, there we stood, two on one side, five on the other, the pit between us, and nobody screwed up high enough to offer the first blow. Silver never moved; he watched them, very upright on his crutch, and looked as cool as ever I saw him. He was brave, and no mistake.
At last Merry seemed to think a speech might help matters.
“Mates,” says he, “there’s two of them alone there; one’s the old cripple that brought us all here and blundered us down to this; the other’s that cub that I mean to have the heart of. Now, mates—”
He was raising his arm and his voice, and plainly meant to lead a charge. But just then—crack! crack! crack!—three musket-shots flashed out of the thicket. Merry tumbled head foremost into the excavation; the man with the bandage spun round like a teetotum and fell all his length upon his side, where he lay dead, but still twitching; and the other three turned and ran for it with all their might.
Before you could wink, Long John had fired two barrels of a pistol into the struggling Merry, and as the man rolled up his eyes at him in the last agony, “George,” said he, “I reckon I settled you.”
At the same moment, the doctor, Gray, and Ben Gunn joined us, with smoking muskets, from among the nutmeg-trees.

events.title: Pursuit and Tense Reunion
detailed_summary: Doctor Livesey shouts for the group to advance quickly to intercept the fleeing mutineers before they can reach their boats.
The party, including Jim, begins a rapid pursuit through the dense vegetation.
Silver, despite his physical handicap, exerts himself tremendously to keep up, pushing his body to the point of near collapse.
By the time the main group reaches the crest of a slope, Silver is significantly behind and on the verge of suffocation from the effort.
Silver calls out to the doctor, indicating that there is no longer a need to hurry.
From their vantage point, they can see the three surviving mutineers still running towards Mizzenmast Hill, clearly cut off from any escape by boat.
The doctor, Gray, Ben Gunn, and Jim sit down to rest, while Silver, wiping his face, slowly catches up to them.
Silver expresses his gratitude to the doctor, acknowledging that their timely arrival saved both him and Jim.
He then addresses Ben Gunn directly, remarking on his unexpected role in these events.
Ben Gunn, visibly flustered, confirms his identity and offers an awkward greeting to Silver.
Silver murmurs reflectively about how Ben Gunn has ultimately outwitted him.

events.text_segment:
“Forward!” cried the doctor. “Double quick, my lads. We must head ’em off the boats.”
And we set off at a great pace, sometimes plunging through the bushes to the chest.
I tell you, but Silver was anxious to keep up with us. The work that man went through, leaping on his crutch till the muscles of his chest were fit to burst, was work no sound man ever equalled; and so thinks the doctor. As it was, he was already thirty yards behind us and on the verge of strangling when we reached the brow of the slope.
“Doctor,” he hailed, “see there! No hurry!”
Sure enough there was no hurry. In a more open part of the plateau, we could see the three survivors still running in the same direction as they had started, right for Mizzenmast Hill. We were already between them and the boats; and so we four sat down to breathe, while Long John, mopping his face, came slowly up with us.
“Thank ye kindly, doctor,” says he. “You came in in about the nick, I guess, for me and Hawkins. And so it’s you, Ben Gunn!” he added. “Well, you’re a nice one, to be sure.”
“I’m Ben Gunn, I am,” replied the maroon, wriggling like an eel in his embarrassment. “And,” he added, after a long pause, “how do, Mr. Silver? Pretty well, I thank ye, says you.”
“Ben, Ben,” murmured Silver, “to think as you’ve done me!”

We set off at a run, the doctor, Gray, Ben Gunn, and I, with Silver hobbling desperately behind us, his face set and his breath coming in great gasps. The underwood closed about our legs, the branches whipped our faces, but we pressed on, the sound of the fugitives crashing through the brush ahead spurring us to greater speed.

At the top of the slope, we paused, breathless, and looked down. Silver was far behind, leaning on his crutch, his face streaming with sweat, and he called out hoarsely, “No need to hurry, doctor. They’re cut off.”

From our vantage, we could see the three remaining mutineers running, panic-stricken, towards Mizzenmast Hill, but the boats were gone, and their escape was hopeless.

We threw ourselves down to rest, and Silver, panting and mopping his brow, at last came up with us. “Doctor,” he said, “I give you my thanks. You’ve saved my life and Jim’s, too, by your timely coming.”

He turned to Ben Gunn, who stood awkwardly, cap in hand. “And you, Ben Gunn,” said Silver, “who’d have thought it of you?”

Ben stammered, “It’s me, Silver. Ben Gunn, sir. And I wishes you well.”

Silver gave a strange, rueful laugh. “Well, Ben Gunn, you’ve bested me in the end, that you have.”

events.title: The Doctor's Revelation of Ben Gunn's Secret Plan
detailed_summary: While Gray is sent back to retrieve a pick-axe abandoned by the fleeing mutineers, the group proceeds leisurely downhill towards the boats, and Doctor Livesey recounts the recent events, a narrative that deeply captivates Silver.
The doctor reveals that Ben Gunn is the true architect of their current good fortune.

During his long, solitary years on the island, Ben Gunn had found the skeleton, taken items from it, discovered the treasure, excavated it (evidenced by his broken pick-axe in the pit), and painstakingly moved it all to a cave on the two-pointed hill at the island's northeast corner.
This treasure had been securely hidden in Ben's cave for two months prior to the Hispaniola's arrival.
The doctor explains that after he learned Ben's secret on the afternoon of the stockade attack, and upon finding the anchorage deserted the following morning, he struck a deal with Silver.

He provided Silver with the now-worthless treasure map and supplies (knowing Ben's cave was well-stocked with salted goat meat) in exchange for safe passage from the stockade to the hill. His primary goals were to escape the malaria-ridden swamp and to secure the treasure.

Addressing Jim, the doctor states that his decision, though painful (implying leaving Jim behind), was made for the benefit of those who had remained loyal, questioning whose fault it was if Jim wasn't among them.

That very morning, anticipating the mutineers' devastating disappointment and Jim's involvement in it, the doctor had rushed to the cave. Leaving the Squire to guard Captain Smollett, he, along with Gray and Ben Gunn, had traversed the island diagonally to be near the pine trees.
However, realizing Jim's party had a head start, the agile Ben Gunn was sent ahead to manage the situation alone.

It was then that Ben Gunn conceived the idea of exploiting his former shipmates' superstitions (the ghostly voice), a tactic so effective that it delayed them sufficiently for the doctor and Gray to arrive and set up their ambush before the treasure-hunters reached the site.

events.text_segment:
The doctor sent back Gray for one of the pick-axes deserted, in their flight, by the mutineers, and then as we proceeded leisurely downhill to where the boats were lying, related in a few words what had taken place. It was a story that profoundly interested Silver; and Ben Gunn, the half-idiot maroon, was the hero from beginning to end.
Ben, in his long, lonely wanderings about the island, had found the skeleton—it was he that had rifled it; he had found the treasure; he had dug it up (it was the haft of his pick-axe that lay broken in the excavation); he had carried it on his back, in many weary journeys, from the foot of the tall pine to a cave he had on the two-pointed hill at the north-east angle of the island, and there it had lain stored in safety since two months before the arrival of the Hispaniola.
When the doctor had wormed this secret from him on the afternoon of the attack, and when next morning he saw the anchorage deserted, he had gone to Silver, given him the chart, which was now useless—given him the stores, for Ben Gunn’s cave was well supplied with goats’ meat salted by himself—given anything and everything to get a chance of moving in safety from the stockade to the two-pointed hill, there to be clear of malaria and keep a guard upon the money.
“As for you, Jim,” he said, “it went against my heart, but I did what I thought best for those who had stood by their duty; and if you were not one of these, whose fault was it?”
That morning, finding that I was to be involved in the horrid disappointment he had prepared for the mutineers, he had run all the way to the cave, and leaving the squire to guard the captain, had taken Gray and the maroon and started, making the diagonal across the island to be at hand beside the pine. Soon, however, he saw that our party had the start of him; and Ben Gunn, being fleet of foot, had been dispatched in front to do his best alone. Then it had occurred to him to work upon the superstitions of his former shipmates, and he was so far successful that Gray and the doctor had come up and were already ambushed before the arrival of the treasure-hunters.

events.text_segment:
“Ah,” said Silver, “it were fortunate for me that I had Hawkins here. You would have let old John be cut to bits, and never given it a thought, doctor.”
“Not a thought,” replied Dr. Livesey cheerily.
And by this time we had reached the gigs. The doctor, with the pick-axe, demolished one of them, and then we all got aboard the other and set out to go round by sea for North Inlet.
This was a run of eight or nine miles. Silver, though he was almost killed already with fatigue, was set to an oar, like the rest of us, and we were soon skimming swiftly over a smooth sea. Soon we passed out of the straits and doubled the south-east corner of the island, round which, four days ago, we had towed the Hispaniola.
As we passed the two-pointed hill, we could see the black mouth of Ben Gunn’s cave and a figure standing by it, leaning on a musket. It was the squire, and we waved a handkerchief and gave him three cheers, in which the voice of Silver joined as heartily as any.
Three miles farther, just inside the mouth of North Inlet, what should we meet but the Hispaniola, cruising by herself? The last flood had lifted her, and had there been much wind or a strong tide current, as in the southern anchorage, we should never have found her more, or found her stranded beyond help. As it was, there was little amiss beyond the wreck of the main-sail. Another anchor was got ready and dropped in a fathom and a half of water. We all pulled round again to Rum Cove, the nearest point for Ben Gunn’s treasure-house; and then Gray, single-handed, returned with the gig to the Hispaniola, where he was to pass the night on guard.

events.title: Arrival at the Cave and the Squire's Stern Judgment of Silver
detailed_summary: A gentle incline leads from the beach to the cave entrance, where Squire Trelawney meets them.
The Squire is cordial and kind to Jim, refraining from any comment, whether praise or blame, regarding Jim's recent escapade.
However, when Long John Silver offers a polite salute, the Squire's face flushes with anger.
The Squire denounces Silver as a 'prodigious villain and imposter' and a 'monstrous imposter'.
He informs Silver that he has been advised against prosecuting him and will therefore not do so.
Despite this, the Squire sternly tells Silver that the responsibility for the dead men hangs around his neck like millstones.
Silver responds with another polite salute and says, 'Thank you kindly, sir'.
The Squire, outraged by Silver's audacity, exclaims, 'I dare you to thank me!', calling his own decision not to prosecute a 'gross dereliction of my duty' and orders Silver to step back.

A gentle slope ran up from the beach to the entrance of the cave. At the top, the squire met us. To me he was cordial and kind, saying nothing of my escapade either in the way of blame or praise. At Silver’s polite salute he somewhat flushed.
“John Silver,” he said, “you’re a prodigious villain and imposter—a monstrous imposter, sir. I am told I am not to prosecute you. Well, then, I will not. But the dead men, sir, hang about your neck like mill-stones.”
“Thank you kindly, sir,” replied Long John, again saluting.
“I dare you to thank me!” cried the squire.

events.text_segment:
And thereupon we all entered the cave. It was a large, airy place, with a little spring and a pool of clear water, overhung with ferns. The floor was sand. Before a big fire lay Captain Smollett; and in a far corner, only duskily flickered over by the blaze, I beheld great heaps of coin and quadrilaterals built of bars of gold. That was Flint’s treasure that we had come so far to seek and that had cost already the lives of seventeen men from the Hispaniola. How many it had cost in the amassing, what blood and sorrow, what good ships scuttled on the deep, what brave men walking the plank blindfold, what shot of cannon, what shame and lies and cruelty, perhaps no man alive could tell. Yet there were still three upon that island—Silver, and old Morgan, and Ben Gunn—who had each taken his share in these crimes, as each had hoped in vain to share in the reward.
“Come in, Jim,” said the captain. “You’re a good boy in your line, Jim, but I don’t think you and me’ll go to sea again. You’re too much of the born favourite for me. Is that you, John Silver? What brings you here, man?”
“Come back to my dooty, sir,” returned Silver.
“Ah!” said the captain, and that was all he said.

events.title: Transporting the Treasure and Its Diverse Nature
detailed_summary: The group undertook the arduous task of moving the substantial treasure from the cave to the Hispaniola, a mile by land and three by sea.
The three remaining mutineers on the island caused little concern, with a single lookout deemed sufficient protection.
Work progressed efficiently: Gray and Ben Gunn ferried treasure by boat, while others, during the boat's absence, accumulated treasure on the beach.
Jim, considered not strong enough for heavy carrying, spent his days in the cave organizing and packing the various coins into bread-bags.
He was captivated by the extraordinary diversity of the coinage, reminiscent of Billy Bones's collection but far larger and more varied.

The collection included currencies from England, France, Spain, and Portugal, featuring images of European monarchs from the past century, alongside peculiar Oriental coins with unusual markings, and pieces of different shapes, some even pierced for wearing.
Jim felt that nearly every type of money in existence was represented, their sheer quantity like autumn leaves, causing him physical strain from bending and sorting.
This labor continued daily, with a significant amount of treasure moved to the ship each evening, yet much more always remained for the next day, all without any sign from the three mutineers.

events.text_segment:
The next morning we fell early to work, for the transportation of this great mass of gold near a mile by land to the beach, and thence three miles by boat to the Hispaniola, was a considerable task for so small a number of workmen. The three fellows still abroad upon the island did not greatly trouble us; a single sentry on the shoulder of the hill was sufficient to ensure us against any sudden onslaught, and we thought, besides, they had had more than enough of fighting.
Therefore the work was pushed on briskly. Gray and Ben Gunn came and went with the boat, while the rest during their absences piled treasure on the beach. Two of the bars, slung in a rope’s end, made a good load for a grown man—one that he was glad to walk slowly with. For my part, as I was not much use at carrying, I was kept busy all day in the cave packing the minted money into bread-bags.
It was a strange collection, like Billy Bones’s hoard for the diversity of coinage, but so much larger and so much more varied that I think I never had more pleasure than in sorting them. English, French, Spanish, Portuguese, Georges, and Louises, doubloons and double guineas and moidores and sequins, the pictures of all the kings of Europe for the last hundred years, strange Oriental pieces stamped with what looked like wisps of string or bits of spider’s web, round pieces and square pieces, and pieces bored through the middle, as if to wear them round your neck—nearly every variety of money in the world must, I think, have found a place in that collection; and for number, I am sure they were like autumn leaves, so that my back ached with stooping and my fingers with sorting them out.
Day after day this work went on; by every evening a fortune had been stowed aboard, but there was another fortune waiting for the morrow; and all this time we heard nothing of the three surviving mutineers.

events.title: Eerie Sounds from Mutineers and Silver's Ambiguous Counsel
detailed_summary: One evening, while the Doctor and Jim were walking on a hill overlooking the island's lowlands, they heard unsettling sounds, a mixture of screams and songs, carried by the wind from the darkness below.
The Doctor identified the noises as coming from the mutineers.
Silver, who had been granted complete freedom and was persistently attempting to regain favor, appeared and suggested the mutineers were drunk.

Jim reflected on Silver's peculiar status: though free, he was generally treated with contempt by most, except for Ben Gunn who still feared him, and Jim himself who felt a complex mix of gratitude and suspicion, especially having witnessed Silver's earlier contemplation of betrayal.
The Doctor responded curtly to Silver, stating the men were either drunk or delirious.
Silver concurred, adding that the distinction mattered little to their own safety.
The Doctor then expressed a surprising humanitarian impulse, saying if he were certain the men were delirious from fever, he would risk his own safety to provide medical help.
Silver strongly advised against this, arguing the mutineers were untrustworthy and would undoubtedly kill the Doctor, thereby weakening their party, and stressed his current allegiance to them.
The Doctor replied with sarcasm, alluding to Silver's own questionable reliability.

At last—I think it was on the third night—the doctor and I were strolling on the shoulder of the hill where it overlooks the lowlands of the isle, when, from out the thick darkness below, the wind brought us a noise between shrieking and singing. It was only a snatch that reached our ears, followed by the former silence.

Silver, I should say, was allowed his entire liberty, and in spite of daily rebuffs, seemed to regard himself once more as quite a privileged and friendly dependent. Indeed, it was remarkable how well he bore these slights and with what unwearying politeness he kept on trying to ingratiate himself with all. Yet, I think, none treated him better than a dog, unless it was Ben Gunn, who was still terribly afraid of his old quartermaster, or myself, who had really something to thank him for; although for that matter, I suppose, I had reason to think even worse of him than anybody else, for I had seen him meditating a fresh treachery upon the plateau. Accordingly, it was pretty gruffly that the doctor answered him.
“Drunk or raving,” said he.
“Right you were, sir,” replied Silver; “and precious little odds which, to you and me.”
“I suppose you would hardly ask me to call you a humane man,” returned the doctor with a sneer, “and so my feelings may surprise you, Master Silver. But if I were sure they were raving—as I am morally certain one, at least, of them is down with fever—I should leave this camp, and at whatever risk to my own carcass, take them the assistance of my skill.”
“Ask your pardon, sir, you would be very wrong,” quoth Silver. “You would lose your precious life, and you may lay to that. I’m on your side now, hand and glove; and I shouldn’t wish for to see the party weakened, let alone yourself, seeing as I know what I owes you. But these men down there, they couldn’t keep their word—no, not supposing they wished to; and what’s more, they couldn’t believe as you could.”
“No,” said the doctor. “You’re the man to keep your word, we know that.”

We knew then that the danger was far from over, and that we must be vigilant if we hoped to survive the days to come.

events.title: Decision to Abandon Mutineers and Final Departure Preparations
detailed_summary: The group heard little more from the three remaining pirates, apart from a distant gunshot once, which they assumed was from the pirates hunting.
A formal council was convened, and the decision was made to abandon the mutineers on the island.
Ben Gunn was immensely pleased by this outcome, and Gray also showed strong support for the decision.

A substantial quantity of supplies was left for the stranded men, including gunpowder, ammunition, the majority of their salted goat meat, some medicines, tools, clothing, a spare sail, rope, and, at the Doctor's specific request, a generous portion of tobacco.
This provisioning was one of their final acts on the island.
Prior to these events, they had completed the task of stowing all the treasure aboard the Hispaniola, and had also loaded sufficient water and the rest of the goat meat for their journey.
Finally, on a clear morning, they managed the difficult task of weighing anchor and sailed out of North Inlet, flying the same flag under which the captain had defended the stockade.

We left a good stock of powder and shot, the bulk of the salt goat, a few medicines, and some other necessaries, tools, clothing, a spare sail, a fathom or two of rope, and by the particular desire of the doctor, a handsome present of tobacco.
